note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: _WHy doe you grieve thus ſtill?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: 'Twold melt a Marble
And tame a ſavage man, to feele my fortune.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: What fortune? I have liv'd this 30. yeares
And run through all theſe follies you call fortunes
Yet never fixt on any good, and conſtant,
But what I made my ſelfe: why ſhould I grieve then,
And that I may mould any way?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You are wide ſtill.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You love a gentlewoman, a young handſome woman,
I have lov'd a thouſand, not ſo few.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You are diſpos'd.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You hope to marry her; 'tis a lawfull calling
And prettily eſteem'd of, but take heed then,
Take heed dear brother of a ſtranger fortune
Then ere you felt yet; fortune my foe is a friend to it.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: 'Tis true I love, dearly, and truly love,
A noble, vertuous, and moſt beauteous maid,
And am belov'd againe.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: That's too much a conſcience
To love all theſe would run me out ô my wits.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Prethee give eare, I am to marry her

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Diſpatch it then, and I'le goe call the Piper.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: But ô the wicked Cuſtomes of this countrey
The barbarous, moſt inhumane, damned Cuſtome

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: 'Tis true, to marry is a cuſtome
In the world; for looke you brother,
Woo'd any man, ſtand plucking for the Ace of Harts,
With one packe of cards all dayes on's life?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You doe not
Or elſe you purpoſe not to underſtand me

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Proceed, I will give care.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: They have a Cuſtome
In this moſt beaſtly countrey, out upon't.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Lets heare it firſt.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: That when a maid is contracted
And ready for the tye o'th Church, the Governour,
He that commands in chiefe, muſt have her maiden-head
Or ranſome it for mony at his pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: How might a man atchieve that place? a rare cuſtome?
An admirable rare cuſtome: and none excepted?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: None, none.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: The rarer ſtill: how could I lay about me?
In this rare office? are they born to it, or choſen?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Both equall damnable.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Me thinks both excellent
Would I were the next heire

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: To this mad fortune
Am I now come, my marriage is proclaim'd.
And nothing can redeem me from this miſchief,

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Shees very young;

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And faire I dare proclaime her
Elſe mine eyes faile,

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Faire as the bud unblaſted.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I cannot blame him then if 'twere mine own caſe.
I would not goe an ace leſſe

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Fye Rutillio
Why do you make your brothers miſery
Your ſport and game?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: There is no paſtime like it

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I look'd for your advice, your timely counſell,
How to avoid this blow, not to be mockt at,
And my afflictions jeer'd.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I tell thee Arnoldo,
An thou wert my Father, as thou art but my brother,
My younger brother too, I muſt be merry
And where there is a wench it can, a young wench,
A handſome wench, and ſooner a good turne too,
An I were to be hangd, thus muſt I handle it.
But you ſhal ſee Sir, I can change this habit
To doe you any ſervice; adviſe what you pleaſe,
And ſee with what devotion I'le attend it?
But yet me thinks, I am taken with this cuſtome.
And could pretend to'th place.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Draw off a little?
Here comes my Miſtris and her Father.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: IA dainty wench;
Woo'd might farme his Cuſtome

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: My deare daughter,
Now to bethink your ſelfe of new advice
Will be too late, later this timeleſſe ſorrow,
No price, nor prayers, can infringe the fate
Your beauty hath caſt on you, my beſt Zenocia,
Be rul'd by me, a Fathers care directs yee,
Looke on the Count, looke cheerfully and ſweetly;
What though he have the power to poſſeſſe yee,
To plucke your maiden honour, and then ſlight yee
By cuſtome, unreſiſtable to enjoy you;
Yet my ſweet childe, ſo much your youth and goodneſs
The beauty of your ſoule, and Saint-like modeſty,
H●ve wonne upon his wilde minde, ſo much charm'd
That all power laid aſide, what Law allows him,
Or ſuddain in fires, kindled from thoſe bright eyes,
He ſues to be your ſervant, fairly, nobly
Forever to be tyed your faithfull Husband:
Conſid●r my beſt childe:

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: I have conſidered

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: The bleſſedneſſe that this breeds too, conſider
Beſides your Fathers Honour, your own peace,
The baniſhment for ever of this cuſtome
This baſe and barbarous uſe, for after once
He has found the happineſſe of holy marriage
And what it is to grow up with one beauty,
How he will ſcorne and kicke at ſuch a heritage
Left him by luſt and lewd progenitors.
All Virgins too, ſhall bleſſe your name, ſhall Saint it,
And like ſo many Pilgrims goe to your ſhrine,
When time has turn'd your beauty into aſhes,
Filld with your pious memory.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Good Father
Hide not that bitter pill, I loth to ſwallow
In ſuch ſweet words:

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: The Count's a handſome Gentleman,
And having him, y'are certaine of a fortune,
A high and noble fortune to attend you:
Where if you fling your love upon this ſtranger
This young Arnoldo, not knowing from what place
Or honourable ſtrain of blood he is ſprung, you ventur
All your owne ſweets, and my long cares to nothing,
Nor are you certaine of his faith; why may not that
Wander as he does, every where?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: No more Sir;
I muſt not heare, I dare not heare him wrongd thus,
Vertue is never wounded, but I ſuffer.
'Tis an ill office in your age, a poore one,
To judge thus weakly: and believe your ſelfe too,
A weaker to betray your innocent daughter,
To his intemp'rate, rude, and wilde embraces,
She hates as Heaven hates falſhood.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: A good wench,
She ſticks cloſe to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: His faith uncertaine?
The nobleneſſe his vertue ſprings from, doubted?
De'e doubt tis day now? or when your body's perfect,
Your ſtomacks well diſpos'd, your pulſes temperate,
De'e doubt you are in health? I tell you Father,
One houre of this mans goodneſſe, this mans Nobleneſſe
Put in the ſcale, againſt the Counts whole being,
Forgive his luſts too, which are halfe his life,
He could no more endure to hold weight with him;
Arnoldoes very looks, are faire examples;
His common and indifferent actions,
Rules and ſtrong ties of vertue: he has my firſt love,
To him in ſacred vow I have given this body,
In him my mind inhabits.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Good wench ſtill

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: And till he fling me off, as undeſerving
Which I confeſſe I am, of ſuch a bleſſing,
But would be loth to finde it ſo—

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: O never;
Never my happy Miſtris, never, never,
When your poor ſervant lives but in your favour,
One foote it'h grave, the other ſhall not linger,
What ſacrifice of thanks, what age of ſervice,
What danger, of more dreadfull looke then death,
What willing martyrdome to crown me conſtant
May merit ſuch a goodneſſe, ſuch a ſweetneſſe?
A love ſo Nobly great, no power can ruine;
Moſt bleſſed maid goe on, the gods that gave this,
This pure unſpotted love, the child of Heaven,
In their own goodneſſe, muſt preſerve and ſave it
And raiſe you a reward, beyond our recompēce;

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I aske but you, a pure maid to poſſeſſe,
And then they have crownd my wiſhes: If I fall then
Goe ſeek ſome better love, mine will debaſe you.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: A pretty innocent foole; well Governour,
Though I think well of your cuſtome, & could wiſh my ſelfe
For this night in your place, heartily wiſh it:
Yet if you play not faire play, and above boord too,
I have a fooliſh gin here, I ſay no more;
I'le tell you what & if your honours guts are not inchanted

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I ſhould now chide you Sir, for ſo declining
The goodneſſe and the grace you have ever ſhewed me,
And your own vertue too, in ſeeking raſhly
To violate that love heaven has appointed,
To wreſt your daughters thoughts, part that affection
That both our hearts have tyed & ſeek to give it,

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: To a wild fellow, that would weary her;
A Canniball, that feedes on the heads of maides,
Then flings their bones and bodies to the Devil,
Would any man of diſcretion venture ſuch a griſtle,
To the rude clawes of ſuch a Cat-a-mountain?
You had better teare her between ● Oaks, a Town bull
Is a meer Stoick to this fellow, a grave Philoſopher,
And a Spaniſh Jennet, a moſt vertuous Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Does this ſeem handſome Sir?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Though I confeſſe
Any man would deſire to have her, and by any meanes,
At any rate too, yet that this common hang-man,
That hath whipt off the heads of a 1000. maids already
That he ſhould gleane the harveſt, ſticks in my ſtomack:
This rogue that breaks young wenches to the ſaddle,
And teaches them to ſtumble ever after;
That he ſhould have her? for my brother now
That is a handſome young fellow; and well thought on,
And will deale tenderly in the buſineſſe;
Or for my ſelfe that have a reputation,
And have ſtudied the concluſions of theſe cauſes
And know the perfect mannage, I'le tel you old Sir,
If I ſhould call you wiſe Sir, I ſhould bely you,
This thing you ſtudy to betray your child to.
This Maiden-monger. When you have done your beſt
And think you have fixt her in the point of honour
Who do you think you have tyed her too? a Surgeon,
I muſt confeſſe an excellent deſector,
One that has cut up more young tender Lamb-pies—

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What I ſpeake Gentlemen, was meer compulſion
No Fathers free-will, nor did I touch your perſon,
With any edge of ſpight; or ſtraine your loves
With any baſe, or hired perſwaſions; Exit.
Witneſſe thſee tears, how well I wiſht your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Theres ſome grace in thee yet, you are determined,
To marry this Count Lady,

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Marry him Rutillio?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Marry him, and lye with him I meane,

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: You cannot meane that,
If you be a true Gentleman, you dare not,
The brother to this man, and one that loves him;
I'le marry the Devill firſt

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: A better choice
And lay his hornes by a hanſomer bedfellow,
A cooler o' my conſcience

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Pray let me aske you;
And my deare Miſtris, be not angry with me
For what I ſhall propound, I am confident,
No promiſe, nor no power, can force your love,
I meane in way of marriage, never ſtirr you,
Nor to forget my faith, no ſtate can wound you.
But for this cuſtome, which this wretched country
Hath wrought into a law, and muſt be ſatisfied;
Where all the pleas of honour, are but laughed at,
And modeſty regarded as a may-game,
What ſhall be here conſidered? power we have none,
To make reſiſtance, nor policie to croſſe it:
'Tis held religion too, to pay this duty.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: I'le dye an Atheiſt then.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: My nobleſt Miſtris
Not that I with it ſo, but ſay it were ſo,
Say you did render up, part of your honour,
For whilſt your will is cleare, all cannot periſh;
Say for one night, you entertained this monſter
Should I eſteeme you worſe, forc'd to this render?
Your minde I know is pure, and full as beauteous;
After this ſhort eclipſe, you would riſe againe
And ſhaking of that cloud, ſpred all your luſtre

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Who made you witty, to undoe your ſelfe, Sir?
Or are you loden, with the love I bring you,
And faine would fling that burthen on another?
Am I growne common in your eyes Arnoldo?
Old, or unworthy of your fellowſhip?
Dee thinke becauſe a woman, I muſt err,
And therefore rather wiſh that fall before hand
Coloured with cuſtome, not to be reſiſted?
Dee love as painters doe, onely ſome peices
Some certaine handſome touches of your Miſtris,
And let the minde paſſe by you, unexamined?
Be not abuſd; with what the maiden veſſell
Is ſeaſond firſt, you underſtand the proverbe.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I am afraid, this thing will make me vertuous,

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Should you lay by the leaſt part of that love
Y'aue ſworne is mine, your youth & faith has given me,
To entertaine another, nay a fairer,
And make the caſe thus deſp'rate, ſhe muſt dye elſe;
D'ee thinke I would give way, or count this honeſt?
Be not deceiv'd, theſe eyes ſhould never ſee you more,
This tongue forget to name you, and this heart
Hate you, as if you were borne, my full Antipathie.
Empire and more imperious love, alone
Rule, and admit no rivalls, the pureſt ſprings
When they are courted by laſcivious land-floods,
Their maiden pureneſſe, and their cooleneſſe periſh.
And though they purge againe to their firſt beauty,
The ſweetneſſe of their taſte, is cleane departed.
I muſt have all or none; and am not worthy
Longer the noble name of wife, Arnoldo,
Then I can bring a whole hart pure & handſom.

sp.speaker: Arnol.
sp.l: I never ſhall deſerve you: not to thanke you;
You are ſo heavenly good, no man can reach you:
I am ſorrie I ſpake ſo raſhly, t'was but to try you.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You might have tryed a thouſnd women ſo,
And 900, fourſcore & 19 ſhould ha'followedy our counſell
Take heed o' clapping ſpurrs to ſuch free cattell,

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: We muſt bethinke us ſuddenly and conſtantly,
And wiſely too, we expect no common danger.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Be moſt aſſur'd, I'le dye firſt.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: An't come to that once,
The Devill picke his bones, that dyes a coward
I'le jog along with you, here comes the Stallion
How ſmug he lookes upon the imagination
Of what he hopes to act? pox on your kidnes,
How they begin to melt? how big he beares
Sure he will leape before us all: what a ſweete company
Of rogues and panders, wait upon his lewdneſſe?
Plague of your chops, you ha' more handſome bitts,
Then a hundred honeſter men, and more deſerving
How the dogg leeres.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: You need not now be jealous
I ſpeake at diſtance to your wife, but when the Preiſt has done
We ſhall grow nearer, and more familiar.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I'le watch you for that tricke, baboone, I'le
Smoke you: the rogue ſwets, as if he had eaten
Graines, hee broyles, if I doe come to the
Baſting of you.

sp.speaker: Arno.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip.
May happily ſpeake this, to fright a ſtranger,
But 'tis not in your honour, to performe it;
The cuſtome of this place, if ſuch there be,
At beſt moſt damnable, may vrge you to it,
But if you be an honeſt man you hate it,
How ever I will preſently prepare
To make her mine, and moſt undovbtedlye;
Beleeve you are abus'd, this cuſtome fain'd to,
And what you now pretend, moſt faire and vertuous.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Goe and beleeve, a good beleife does well Sir;
And you Sir, cleare the place, but leave her here.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Your Lordſhips pleaſure

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: That anon Arnoldo,
This is but talke

sp.speaker: Rut
sp.l: Shall we goe off?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: By any meanes
I know ſhe has pious thoughts enough to guard her:
Beſides, heres nothing due to him till the tye be done
Nor dare he offer.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Now doe I long to worry him:
Pray have a care to the main chance. Ex. Arn. and Rut.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Pray Sir feare not

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Now, what ſay you to me?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Sir it becomes
The modeſtie, that maides are ever borne with,
To uſe few words.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Doe you ſee nothing in me
Nothing to catch your eyes nothing of wonder,
The common mould of men, come ſhort, and want in?
Doe you read no future fortune for your ſelfe here?
And what a happineſſe, it may be to you,
To have him honour you, all women aime at?
To have him love you Lady, that man love you,
The beſt, and the moſt beauteous, have run mad for?
Looke and be wiſe, you have a favour offerd you
I doe not euery day propound to women;
You are a prettie one: and though each hower,
I am glutted, with the ſacrifice of beautie,
I may be brought, as you may handle it,
To caſt ſo good a grace and likeing on you,
You underſtand, come kiſſe me, and be joyfull,
I giue you leave.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Faith Sir, twill not ſhew handſome;
Our ſex his bluſhing, full of feare, unskild too,
In theſe alarums.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Learne then and be perfect

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I doe beſeech your honour pardon me,
And take ſome skilfull one, can hold you play,
I am a foole.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I tell thee maide I love thee,
Let that word make thee happie, ſo farr love thee,
That though I may enjoy thee without ceremony,
I will deſcend ſo lowe, to marry thee,
Me thinkes I ſee the race, that ſhall ſpring from us,
Some Princes, ſome great Souldiers

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I am afraid.
Your honours couzen'd in this calculation;
For certaine, I ſhall nere haue a child by you.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Becauſe I muſt not thinke to marry you,
I dare not Sir, the ſtep betwixt your honour,
And my poore humble State.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I will deſcend to thee,
And buoye thee up.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I'le ſinke to th' Center firſt,
Why would your Lordſhip marry, and confine that pleaſure,
You ever have had freely caſt upon you?
Take heed my Lord this marring is a mad matter,
Lighter a paire of ſheckles will hang on you,
And quieter a quartaine feaver finde you
If you wed me I muſt enjoy you onely,
Your eyes muſt be cald home, your thoughs in cages,
To ſing to no eares then but mine; your hart bound
The cuſtome, that your youth was euer nurſt in,
Muſt be forgot, I ſhall forget my duty elſe,
And how that will appeare,

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Wee'le talke of that more

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Beſides I tell yee, I am naturally,
As all young women are, that ſhew like handſome,
Exceeding proud, being cōmended, monſtrous. Boy ready for the Songs
Of an unquiet temper, ſeldome pleaſ'd.
Unleſſe it be with infinite obſervance.
Which you were never bred to; once well angerd,
As every croſſe in us, provokes that paſſion,
And like a Sea, I roule, toſſe, and chaſe a weeke after.
And then all miſcheife I can think upon,
Abuſing of your bed the leaſt and pooreſt,
I tell you what you'le finde, and in theſe fitts,
This little beauty, you are pleaſed to honour,
Will be ſo chang'd, ſo alterd to an uglineſſe,
To ſuch a vizard, ten to one, I dye too,
Take't then upon my death you murderd me,

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Away, away fool, why doſt thou proclaime theſe
To prevent that in me, thou haſt choſen in another

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Him I have choſen, I can rule and maſter,
Temper to what I pleaſe, you are a great one
Of a ſtrong will to bend, I dare not venture,
Be wiſe my Lord, and ſay you were well counſeld,
Take mony for my ranſome, and forget me,
Twill be both ſafe, and noble for your honour,
And whereſoever my fortunes ſhall conduct me,
So worthy mentions I ſhall render of you
So vertuous and ſo faire.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: You will not marry me:

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I doe beſeech your honour, be not angry
At what I ſay, I cannot love yee, dare not;
But ſuch a ranſome, for the flowre you covet

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: No money, nor no prayers, ſhall redeeme that,
Not all the art you have

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Set your owne price Sir.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Goe to your wedding, neuer kneel to me
When that's done, you are mine, I will enjoy you:
Your teares do nothing, I will not looſe my cuſtome
To caſt upon my ſelfe an Empires fortune Exit.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: My minde ſhall not pay this cuſtome, cruel man

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Your body wil content me: I'le look for you, Ex.

div.stage: Enter Charino and ſervants in blackes. Covering the place with blackes.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Strew all your withered flowers, your Autumn ſweets
By the hot Sun raviſht of bud and beauty
Thus round about her Bride-bed hang thoſe blacks ther
The emblemes of her honour loſt; all joy Bowle of wine ready.
That leades a Virgin to receive her Lover,
Keepe from this place all fellow-maides that bleſſe her,
And bluſhing and unlooſe her Zone, keep from her:
No merry noiſe nor luſty ſongs be heard here,
Nor ful cups crownd with wine, make the rooms giddy;
This is no maſque of mirth, but murdered honour.
Sing mournfully that ſad Epithalamion,
I gave thee now: and prethee let thy Lute weepe.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: How now, what livery's this? doe you call this a wedding?
This is more like a funerall.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: It is one,
And my poor Daughter going to her grave,
To his moſt loth'd embraces that gapes for her.
Make the Earles bed ready, is the marriage done Sir?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Yes they are knit; but muſt this ſlubberdegullion
Have her maiden-head now?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Theres no avoyding it?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And there's the ſcaffold where ſhe muſt looſe it.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: The bed ſir?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: No way to wipe his mouldy chaps?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: That we know

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: To any honeſt wel-deſerving fellow,
And 'twere but to a merry Cobler, I could ſit ſtill now,
I love the game ſo well, but that this puckfiſt,
This univerſall rutter, fare ye well Sir;
And if you have any good prayers, put 'em forward,
There may be yet a remedy.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I wiſh it, Exit Rut.
And all my beſt devotions offer to it.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Now is this tye diſpathc'd?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I thinke it be Sir:

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: And my bed ready? wine

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: There you may quickly find Sir,
Such a loth'd preparation.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Never grumble,
Nor fling a diſcontent upon my pleaſure
It muſt and ſhall be done: give me ſome wine,
And fill it till it leape upon my lips:
Here's to the fooliſh maiden head you wot of,
The toy I muſt take paines for

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I beſeech your Lord-ſhip
Load not a Fathers love,

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Pledge it Charino,
Or by my life I'le make thee pledge thy laſt
And be ſure ſhe be a maid, a perfect Virgin,
(I will not have my expectation dul'd)
Or your old pate goes off. I am hot and fiery
And my bloud beates alarums through my body
And fancie high. You of my guard retire,
And let me heare no noyſe about the lodging
But muſick and ſweet ayres, now fetch your daughter,
And bid the coy wench put on all her beauties,
All her enticements, out-bluſh damask roſes,
And dim the breaking Eaſt with her bright Chriſtalls.
I am all on fire, away

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: And I am frozen. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Zenocia with Bow and Quiver, an Arrow bent, Arnoldo and Rutillio after her, arm'd.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Come feareleſſe on

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Nay an I budge from thee
Beate me with durty ſticks.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: What Maſque is this?
What pretty fancy to provoke me high?
The beauteous Huntreſſe, fairer far, and ſweeter;
Diana ſhewes an Ethiop to this beauty
Protected by two Virgin Knights.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: That's a lye,
A loud one, if you knew as much as I doe
The guard's diſpers'd

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Fortune I hope invites us

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I can no longer hold, ſhe puls my heart from me

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Stand, & ſtand fixt, move not a foote, nor ſpeak not,
For if thou doeſt' upon this point thy death ſits.
Thou miſerable, baſe, and ſordid lecher,
Thou ſcum of noble blood, repent and ſpeedily,
Repent thy thouſand thefts, from helpleſſe virgins,
Their innocence betrayed to thy embraces.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: The baſe dishonour, that thou doeſt to ſtrangers,
In glorying to abuſe the lawes of marriage,
Thy Infamy thou haſt flung upon thy countrey,
In nouriſhing this black and barbarous cuſtome

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: My guard.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: One word more, and thou dieſt.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: One ſillable
That tends to any thing, but I beſeech you,
And as y'are Gentlemen tender my caſe,
And I'le thruſt my javeling downe thy throate
Thou Dogg-whelpe, thou, pox upon thee, what
Should I call the? Pompean,
Thou kiſſe my Lady? thou ſcowr her chamber pot:
Thou have a mayden head? a mottly coate,
You great blinde foole, farewell and be hanged to yee,
Looſe no time Lady.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Pray take your pleaſure Sir,
And ſo wee'l take our leaves

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: We are determined,
Dye, before yield

sp.speaker: Ar●
sp.l: Honour, and a faire grave

sp.speaker: Zen
sp.l: Before a luſt full bed, ſo for our fortunes.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Du cat a whee, good count, cry, preethe cry,
O what a wench haſt thou loſt? cry you great booby. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: And is ſhe gone then, am I diſhonoured thus
Cozend and baffuld? my guard there no man anſwer?
My guard I ſay, Sirra you knew of this plott.
Where are my guard? Ile ha' your life you villaine.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You politique old thiefe.
Heaven ſend her far enough Enter Guard.
And let me paye the ranſome.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Did your honour call us?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Poſt every way, and preſently recover,
The two ſtrange Gentlemen, and the faire Lady,

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: This day was married Sir.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: We ſaw e'm
Making with all maine ſpeed to'th port.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Away villains. Ex. Gard:
Recover her, or I ſhall dye; deale truely,
Didſt not thou know,

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: By all thats good I did not
If your honour meane their flight, to ſay I grieve for that,
Will be to lye; you may handle me as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Be ſure, with all the cruelty, with all the rigor,
For thou haſt robd mee villaine of a treaſure.

div.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: They'r all aboord, a bark rode ready for 'em,
And now are under ſayle and paſt recovery

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Rig me a ſhip with all the ſpeed that may be,
I will not looſe her: thou her moſt falſe Father,
Shalt go along; and if I miſſe her, heare me,
Whole day will I ſtudie to deſtroy thee.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I ſhall be joyfull of it; and ſo you'll finde me.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Manuell du ſoſa. and Guiomar.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I heare, and ſee, too much of him, and that
Compells me Madam, though unwillingly,
To wiſh I had no uncles part in him,
And much I feare, the comfort of a Son
You will not long enjoy.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: 'Tis not my fault,
And therefore from his guilt my innocence
Cannot be taynted, ſince his Fathers death
(Peace to his ſoule) a Mothers prayers and care,
Were never wanting, in his education.
His child-hood I paſſe, as being brought up
Under my wing; and growing ripe for ſtudy,
I overcame the tenderneſſe, and joye
I had to looke upon him, and provided
The choiceſt Maſters, and of greateſt name
Of Salamanca, in all liberall Arts.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: To train his youth up.
I muſt witneſſe that.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: How there he proſpered, to the admiration,
Of all that knew him, for a generall ſcholler,
Being one of note, before he was a man,
Is ſtill remembred in that Academy,
From thence I ſent him to the Emperours court,
Attended like his Fathers Sonne and there
Maintaind him, in ſuch bravery and height,
As did become a courtier.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Twas that ſpoild him, my Nephew had beene hapy
The court's a ſchoole indeed, in which ſome few
Learne vertuous principles, but moſt forget,
What ever they brought thither good and honeſt.
Trifling is there in practice, ſerious actions,
Are obſolete and out of uſe, my Nephew
Had beene a happy man, had he ne're knowne
What's there in grace, and faſhion.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I have heard yet,
That while he liv'd in court, the Emperour
Tooke notice of his carriage and good parts,
The grandees did not ſcorne his company,
And of the greateſt Ladies he was held,
A compleate Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: He indeed daunc'd well,
A turne o'th toe, with a loftie tricke or two,
To argue nimbleneſſe, and a ſtrong backe,
Will go farr with a Madam: 'tis moſt true,
That hee's an excellent ſcholler, and he knowes it;
An exact courtier, and he knowes that too;
He has fought thrice, and come off ſtill with honour,
Which he forgets not

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Nor I have much reaſon.
To greive his fortune that way,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You are miſtaken,
Proſperity does ſearch a Gentlemans temper,
More then his adverſe fortune: I have knowen
Many, and of rare parts from their ſucceſſe
In private duells, raiſ'd up to ſuch a pride,
And ſo transformed from what they were, that all
That lov'd them truely, wiſh'd they had fallen in them.
I need not write examples, in your ſone,
'Tis too apparent; for ere Don Duarte,
Made tryall of his valour, he indeed was
Admired for civill courteſy, but now
Hee's ſwolne ſo high, out of his owne aſſurance,
Of what he dares do, that he ſeekes occaſions,
Unjuſt occaſions, grounded on blinde paſſion,
Ever to be in quarrels, and this makes him
Shund of all faire ſocieties.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Would it were
In my weake power to help it: I will uſe
With my entreaties th' authority of a mother,
As you may of an Vncle, and enlarge it
With your command, as being a governor
To the great King in Lisborne.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Here he comes.
We are unſeene, obſerve him.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Boye

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: What ſaith the ſpaniſh captaine that I ſtrooke,
To my bold challenge?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: He refuſ'd to read it.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Why didſt not leave it there?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: I did my Lord,
But to no purpoſe, for he ſeemes more willing
To ſit downe with the wrongs, then to repaire
His honour by the ſword; he knowes too well,
That from your Lordſhip nothing can be got
But more blowes, and diſgraces.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Hee's a wretch,
A miſerable wretch, and all my furie
Is loſt upon him; holds the maſque, appointed
Ith' honour of Hippolita:

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: 'Tis broke off.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: The reaſon?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: This was one, they heard your Lordſhip
Was by the Ladies choiſe to lead the dance,
And therefore they, too well aſſur'd how farr
You would out ſhine e'm, gave it ore and ſaied
They would not ſerve for foiles to ſet you off.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: They at their beſt are ſuch, and ever ſhall be
Where I appeare.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Doe you note his modeſtie?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: But was there nothing elſe pretended?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Yes,
Young Don Alonzo, the great Captaines Nephew,
Stood on compariſons.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: With you,
And openly profeſs'd, that all precedence,
His birth and ſtate conſidered, was due to him
Nor were your Lordſhip to contend with one
So farr above you.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I looke downe upon him
With ſuch contempt and ſcorne, as on my ſlave,
Hee's a name onely, and all good in him,
He muſt derive, from his great grandſires aſhes,
For had not their victorious acts bequeath'd,
His titles to him, and wrot on his forehead,
This is a Lord, he had liv'd unobſerv'd
By any man of marke, and died as one
Among the common route, compaire with me?
'Tis giant-like ambition; I know him,
And know my ſelfe, that man is truely noble,
And he may juſtly call that worth his owne,
Which his deſerts have purchac'd, I could wiſh
My birth were more obſcure, my freinds and kinſmen
Of leſſer power, or that my provident Father,
Had been like to that riotous Emperour
That choſe his belly for his onely heire;
For being of no family then, and poore
My vertues whereſo'er I liv'd, ſhould make
That kingedome my inheritance.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Strange ſelfe love

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: For if I ſtudied the countries lawes,
I ſhould ſo eaſily, ſound all their depth,
And riſe up ſuch a wonder, that the pleaders,
That now are in moſt practice, and eſteeme
Should ſtarve for want of clients: If I traveld,
Like wiſe Vlyſſes to ſee men and manners,
I would returne in act, more knowing, then
Homer could fancie him; If a Phyſitian,
So oft I would reſtore death wounded men,
That where I liv'd, Gallen ſhould not be nam'd,
And he that joyn'd againe the ſcatterd limbs
Of torne Hippolitus ſhould be forgotten.
I could teach Ovid courtſhip, how to win,
A Julia, and enjoy her, though her dower
Were all the Sun gives light to: and for armes
Were the Perſian hoſt that drank up Rivers, added
To the Turkes preſent powers, I could direct,
Command, and marſhall them.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And yet you know not
To rule your ſelfe, you would not to a boy elſe
Like Plautus Braggart boaſt thus.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: All I ſpeake,
In act I can make good,

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Why then being Maſter,
Of ſuch and ſo good parts doe you deſtroy them,
With ſelfe opinion or like a rich miſer,
Hoard up the treaſures you poſſeſs, imparting,
Nor to your ſelfe nor others, the uſe of them?
They are to you, but like inchanted viands,
On which you ſeeme to feed, yet pine with hunger;
And thoſe ſo rare perfections in my ſon
Which would make others happy, renders me
A wretched Mother.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You are too inſolent.
And thoſe too many excellencies, that feed
Your pride, turne to a pluriſy, and kill
That which ſhould nouriſh vertue; dare you think
All bleſſings are conferd on you alone.
Ya're groſly couſend; there's no good in you,
Which others have not: are you a Scholler? ſo
Are many, and as knowing: are you valiant?
Waſte not that courage then in braules, but ſpend it
In the warres, in ſervice of your King and Countrey.

sp.speaker: Duarte.
sp.l: Yes, ſo I might be generall, no man lives,
That's worthy to command me

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sir, in Lisborne
I am: and you ſhall know it; every hower
I am troubled with complaints of your behaviour
From men of all conditions, and all ſexes.
And my authority, which you preſume
Will beare you out, in that you are my Nephew,
No longer ſhall protect you, for I vowe
Though all that's paſt I pardon, I will puniſh
The next fault with as much ſeverity
As if you were a ſtranger, reſt aſſur'd on't.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: And by that love you ſhould beare, or that duty
You owe a Mother, once more I command you
To caſt this hautineſſe off; which if you doe,
All that is mine, is yours, if not, expect
My prayers, and vowes, for your converſion onely,
But never meanes nor favour. Exit. Manuell and Guiomar.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I am tutord
As I if I were a child ſtill, the baſe peaſants
That feare, and envy my great worth, have done this;
But I will finde them out, I will aboord
Yet my diſguiſe, I have too long been idle
Nor will I curbe my ſpirit, I was born free,
And will purſue the courſe beſt liketh me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Devide the ſpoile amongſt you, this fair captive
I only challenge for my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: You have wonne her
And well deſerve her: twenty yeares I have liv'd
A Burgeſſe of the Sea, and have been preſent
At many a deſperate fight, but never ſaw
So ſmall a barque with ſuch incredible valour
So long defended, and againſt ſuch odds,
And by two men ſcarce arm'd too.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: 'Twas a wonder.
And yet the courage they expreſt being taken
And the contempt of death wan more upon me
Then all they did, when they were free: me-thinkes
I ſee them yet when they were brought aboord us,
Diſarm'd and ready to be put in fetters
How on the ſuddain, as if they had ſworn,
Never to taſte the bread of ſervitude,
Both ſnatching up their ſwords, and from this Virgin,
Taking a farewell only with their eyes,
They leapt into the Sea.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: Indeed 'twas rare.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: It wrought ſo much on me, that but I feard,
The great ſhip that purſued us, our own ſafety
Hindring my charitable purpoſe to 'em,
I would have took 'em up, and with their lives
They ſhould have had their liberties.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: O too late
For they are loſt, for ever loſt

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Take comfort
'Tis not impoſſible, but that they live yet,
For when they left the ſhips they were within
A league o'th ſhore, and with ſuch ſtrength and cunning
They ſwimming, did delude the riſing billows,
With one hand making way, and with the other,
Their bloudy ſwords advancſt, threatning the Sea-gods
With war, unleſſe they brought them ſafely off,
That I am almoſt confident they live
And you again may ſee them.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: In that hope
I brook a wretched being, till I am
Made certaine of their fortunes, but they dead
Death hath ſo many doores to let out life,
I will not long ſurvive them.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Hope the beſt,
And let the courteous uſage you have found,
Not uſuall in men of Warre perſwade you
To tell me your condition.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: You know it,
A Captive, my fate and your power have made me,
Such I am now, but what I was it skills not:
For they being dead, in whom I only live
I dare not challenge family, or country
And therefore Sir enquire not, let it ſuffice,
I am your ſervant, and a thankfull ſervant,
(If you will call that ſo, which is but duty)
I ever will be, and my honour ſafe,
Which nobly hitherto ye have preſerv'd
No ſlavery can appear in ſuch a forme,
Which with a maſculine conſtancy, I will not
Boldly looke on and ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: You miſtake me:
That you are made my priſoner, may prove
The birth of your good fortune. I doe finde
A winning language in your tongue and looks;
Nor can a ſuite by you mov'd be deni'd,
And therefore of a priſoner you muſt be
The Victors advocate

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: A Lady.
In whom all graces that can perfect beauty
Are friendly met, I grant that you are faire:
And had I not ſeen her before, perhaps
I might have ſought to you

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: This I heare gladly,

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: To this incomparable Lady I will give you,
(Yet being mine, you are already hers)
And to ſerve her is more then to be free,
At leaſt I think ſo: and when you live With her,
If you will pleaſe to think on him that brought you
To ſuch a happineſſe, for ſo her bountie
Will make you think her ſeruice, you ſhall euer
Make me at your devotion

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: All I can doe,
Reſt you aſſur'd of.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: At night I'le preſent you,
Till when I am your guard

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Ever your ſervant. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: To what are we reſerv'd?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Troth tis uncertaine,
Drowning we have ſcap'd miraculouſly, and
Stand faire for ought I know for hanging; money
We have none, nor ere are like to have; 'tis
To be doubted: beſides we are ſtrangers,
Wondrous hungry ſtrangers; and charity
Growing cold, and miracles ceaſing,
Without a Conjurers help, cannot finde
When we ſhall eate agen.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Theſe are no wants
If put in ballance, with Zenocias loſſe;
In that alone, all miſeries are ſpoken:
O my Rutillio, when I think on her,
And that which ſhe may ſuffer, being a captive,
Then I could curſe my ſelfe, almoſt thoſe powers
That ſend me from the fury of the Ocean.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You have loſt a wife indeed, a faire and chaſt one,
Two bleſſings, not found often in one woman;
But ſhe may be recovered, queſtionleſſe
The ſhip that took us was of Portugall
And he in Lisbon, by ſome meanes or other
We may heare of her.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: In that hope I live.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And ſo do I, but hope is a poor ſallad
To dine and ſup with, after a two dayes faſt too,
Have you no money left?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Not a Denier,

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Nor any thing to pawn? 'tis now in faſhion,
Having a Miſtris, ſure you ſhould not be
Without a neate hiſtoricall ſhirt.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: For ſhame
Talke not ſo poorly.
I muſt talke of that
Neceſſity prompts us to, for beg I cannot,
Nor am I made to creep in at a window,
To filch to feed me, ſomething muſt be done,
And ſuddenly reſolve on't.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: What are theſe?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: One by his habite is a Jew

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: No more:
Thou art ſure that's he.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Moſt certaine.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: How long is it
Since firſt ſhe ſaw him?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Some two hours. Exit Ser.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Be gone—let me alone to work him.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: How he eyes you,
Now he moves, towards us, in the Devills name
What would he with us?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Innocence is bold:
Nor can I feare

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: That you are poore and ſtrangers,
I eaſily perceive

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: But that you'le help us,
Or any of your tribe, we dare not hope Sir.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Why think you ſo?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Becauſe you are a Jew Sir,
And courteſies come ſooner from the Devill
Then any of your Nation.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: We are men,
And have like you, compaſſion when we finde
Fit ſubjects for our bounty, and for proofe
That we dare give, and freely, not to you Sir,
Pray ſpare your paines, there's gold, ſtand not amaz'd,
'Tis current I aſſure you

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Take it man.
Sure thy good Angel is a Jew, and comes Tapers ready.
In his own ſhape to help thee: I could wiſh now,
Mine would appeare ſo, like a Turke.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I thank you,
But yet muſt tell you, if this be the prologue
To any bad act, you would have me practice
I muſt not take it.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: This is but the earneſt
Of that which is to follow, and the bond
Which you muſt ſeale to for't, is your advancement,
Fortune with all that's in her power to give,
Offers her ſelfe up to you; entertaine her,
And that which Princes have kneel'd for in vaine
Preſents it ſelfe to you.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: 'Tis above wonder

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: But far beneath the truth, in my relation
Of what you ſhall poſſeſſe, if you embrace it.
There is an hour in each mans life appointed
To make his happineſſe if then he ſeize it,
And this, (in which, beyond all expectation,
You are invited to your good) is yours,
If you dare follow me, ſo, if not, hereafter
Expect not the like offer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: 'Tis no viſion.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: 'Tis gold I'm ſure. We muſt like brothers ſhare,
There's for you; by this light I'me glad I have it.
There are few gallants, (for men may be ſuch
And yet want gold, yea and ſometimes ſilver,)
But would receive ſuch favours from the Divel,
Though he appeared like a broker, and demanded
Sixty ith' hundred.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Wherefore ſhould I feare,
Some plot upon my life? 'tis now to me
Not worth the keeping. I will follow him,
Farewell, wiſh me good fortune, we ſhall meete
Againe I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Or I'le ne're truſt Jew more. Exit Arnoldo.
Nor Chriſtian for his ſake— plague o' my ſtars,
How long might I have walkt without a cloake,
Before I ſhould have met with ſuch a fortune?
We elder Brothers, though we are pro●●● men,
Ha not the luck. Ha' too much beard, th●● ſpoiles us;
The ſmooth chin carries all? whats here to do now?

div.stage: Enter Duart, Alonſo, and a Page.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I'le take you as I finde you:

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: That were baſe—you ſee I am unarm'd.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Out with your bodkin
Your pocket dagger, your ſteletto, out with it,
Or by this hand i'le kill you: ſuch as you are
Have ſtudied the undoing of poore Cutlers,
And made all manly weapons out of faſhion:
You carry Poniards to murder men,
Yet dare not wear a ſword to guard your Honour.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: that's true indeed: upon my life this gallant
Is brib'd to repeale baniſht ſwords.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I'le ſhew you
The difference now, between a Spaniſh rapier
And your pure piſa.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Let me fetch a ſword,
Upon mine honour I'le returne.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Not ſo Sir.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Or lend me yours I pray you, and take this,

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: To be diſgrac'd as you are, no I thank you
Spight of the faſhion, while I live, I am Lights ready.
Inſtructed to goe arm'd: what folly 'tis
For you that are a man, to put your ſelfe
Into your enemies mercie.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Yield it quickly
Or I'le cut off your hand, and now diſgrace you,
Thus kicke and baffle you: as you like this
You may again prefer complaints againſt me
To my Uncle and my Mother, and then think
To make it good with a poniard.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I am paid
For being of the faſhion.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Get a ſword,
Then if you dare, redeeme your reputation:
You know I am eaſily found: Ile adde this to it
To put you in mind.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You are too inſolent,
And do inſult too much on the advantage,
Of that which your unequall weapon gave you,
More then your valour.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: This to me you peaſant?
Thou art not worthy of my foote poore fellow,
Tis ſcorne, not pitty, makes me give thee life:
Kneele down and thank me for't: how, do you ſtare?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I have a ſword Sir, you ſhall find, a good one;
This is no ſtabbing guard.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Wert thou thrice arm'd,
Thus yet I durſt attempt thee:

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Then have at you,
I ſcorne to take blows.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: O I am ſlaine.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Help! murther, murther!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Shift for your ſelfe you are dead elſe,
You have kill'd the Governours Nephew.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Raiſe the ſtreetes there.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: If once you are beſet you cannot ſcape,
Will you betray your ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Undone for ever. Exit Rut. & Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Who makes this out-cry,

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: O my Lord is murdered;
This way he tooke, make after him,
Help help there. Exit Page.

sp.speaker: 2. Off.
sp.l: 'Tis Don Duart.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: Pride has got a fall
He was ſtill in quarrels, ſcorn'd us Peace-makers,
And all our bill-authority, now ha's paid for't.
You ha' met with your match Sir now, bring off his body
And beare it to the Governour. Some purſue
The murderer; yet if he ſcape, it skills not;
Were I a Prince, I would reward him for't,
He ha's ridde the City of a turbulent beaſt,
There's few will pitty him: but for his Mother
I truly grieve indeed, ſhee's a good Lady. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Hee's not i'th houſe,

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: No madam:

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Haſte and ſeek him,
Goe all and every where, I'le not to bed
Till you returne him, take away the lights too,
The Moone lends me too much, to finde my feares,
And thoſe devotions I am to pay
Are written in my heart, not in this booke, Kneele.
And I ſhall reade them there without a taper, Exit Serv.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I am purſued; all the Ports are ſtopt too;
Not any hope to eſcape, behind, before me,
On either ſide I am beſet, curſed fortune
My enemie on the Sea, and on the Land too,
Redeem'd from one affliction to another:
Would I had made the greedy waves my tombe
And dyed obſcure, and innocent, not as Neroe
Smear'd ore with blood. Whither have my fears brought me?
I am got into a houſe, the doors all open,
This, by the largeneſſe of the roome, the hangings,
And other rich adornments, gliſtring through
The ſable maſque of night, ſayes it belongs
To one of meanes and ranke: no ſervant ſtirring?
Murmur nor whiſper?

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: By the voice,
This is a woman.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Who waites there?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: 'Tis the Lady of the houſe
I'le flie to her protection.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Speak, what are you?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Of all that ever breath'd, a man moſt wretched.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I am ſure you are a man of moſt ill manners,
You could not with ſo little reverence elſe
Preſſe to my private chamber. Whither would you,
Or what do you ſeeke for?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Gracious woman heare me;
I am a ſtranger, and in that I anſwer
All your demands, a moſt unfortunate ſtranger,
That cald unto it by my enemies pride,
Have left him dead it'h ſtreets, Juſtice purſues me,
And for that life, I tooke unwillingly,
And in a faire defence, I muſt loſe mine,
Unleſſe you in your charity protect me.
Your houſe is now my ſanctuary, and the Altar,
I gladly would take hold of your ſweet mercy.
By all that's deare unto you, by your vertues,
And by your innocence, that needs no forgiveneſſe
Take pitty on me.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Are you a Caſtillian:

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: No Madam, Italy claims my birth.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I ask not
With purpoſe to betray you, if you were
Ten thouſand times a Spaniard, the nation
We Portugals moſt hate, I yet would ſave you
If it lay in my power: lift up theſe hangings;
Behind my Beds head theres a hollow place,
Into which enter; ſo, but from this ſtir not
If the Officers come, as you expect they will doe,
I know they owe ſuch reverence to my lodgings
That they will eaſily give credit to me
And ſearch no further.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: The bleſt Saints pay for me
The infinite debt I owe you.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: How he quakes?
Thus far I feele his heart beate, be of comfort,
Once more I give my promiſe for your ſafety,
All men are ſubject to ſuch accidents,
Eſpecially the valiant; and who knows not,
But that the charity I afford this ſtranger
My only Son elſe-where may ſtand in neede of?

div.stage: Enter Officers and ſervants with the body of Duart—Page.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: Now Madam, if your wiſedome ever could
Raiſe up defences againſt floods of ſorrow
That haſt to overwhelme you, make true uſe of
Your great diſcretion.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Your only ſonne
My Lord Duart's ſlaine.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: His murtherer, purſued by us
Was by a boy diſcovered
Entring your houſe, and that induced us
To preſſe into it for his apprhenſion.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Oh?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: Sure her heart is broke.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Stand off,
My ſorrow is ſo deare and pretious to me,
That you muſt not partake it, ſuffer it Hold a purſe ready.
Like wounds that do breed inward to diſpatch me.
O my Duart, ſuch an end as this
Thy pride long ſince did propheſie; thou art dead,
And to encreaſe my miſery, thy ſad mother?
Muſt make a wilfull ſhipwrack of her vow
Or thou fall unreveng'd. My ſoule's divided
And piety to a ſon, and true performance
Of hoſpitable duties to my gueſt,
That are to others Angels, are my furies.
Vengeance knocks at my heart, but my word given
Denies the entrance, is no medium left,
But that I muſt protect the murderer
Or ſuffer in that faith he made his Altar?
Motherly love give place, the fault made this way,
To keep a vow, to which high heaven is witneſſe,
Heaven may be pleas'd to pardon.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis too late
Hee's gone, paſt all recovery: now reproofe
Were but unſeaſonable when I ſhould give comfort,
And yet remember Siſter.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: O forbeare,
Search for the murtherer, and remove the body,
And as you thinke fit, give it buriall.
Wretch that I am, uncapable of all comfort,
And therefore I intreate my friends and kinsfolk,
And you my Lord, for ſome ſpare to forbeare
Your courteous viſitations.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: We obey you. Exeunt omnes with the body. Manet Guiomar.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: My ſpirits come back, and now deſpaire reſignes
Her place againe to hope.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: What ere thou art
To whom I have given meanes of life, to witneſſe
With what religion I have kept my promiſe,
Come fearleſſe forth, but let thy face be cover'd,
That I hereafter be not forct to know thee,
For motherly affection may returne
My vow once paid to heaven. Thou haſt taken from me,
The reſpiration of my heart, the light
Of my ſwoln eyes, in his life that ſuſtain'd me,
Yet my word given to ſave you, I make good,
Becauſe what you did, was not done with malice,
You are not knowne, there is no marke about you
That can diſcover you; let not feare betray you.
With all convenient ſpeed you can, flie from me
That I may never ſee you; and that want
Of meanes may be no let unto your journie,
There are a hundred Crownes: you are at the doore now,
And ſo farewell for ever.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Let me firſt fall
Before your feete, and on them pay the duty
I owe your goodneſſe; next all bleſſings to you,
And heaven reſtore the joyes I have bereft you,
With full increaſe hereafter, living be
The Goddeſſe ſtil'd of Hoſpitalitie.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Fling off theſe ſullen cloudes, you are enterd now
Into a houſe of joy and hapineſſe,
I have prepar'd a bleſſing for ye.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Thanke ye

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You are peeviſh
And know not whē ye are freinded, I have uſ'd thoſe means
My ſtate would rather aske a curſe,
The Lady of this houſe, the noble Lady,
Will take ye as her owne, and uſe ye graciouſly:
Make much of what you are, Miſtris of that beautie,
And expoſe it not to ſuch betraying ſorrowes:
When ye are old, and all thoſe ſweets hang witherd,
Then ſit and ſight

sp.speaker: Zen
sp.l: My Autum is not farr off,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Have you told your Lady

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I have told her
Both of your noble ſervice, and your preſent,
Which ſhe accepts,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I ſhould be bleſt to ſee her.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: That now you cannot doe: ſhe keeps her Chamber
Not well diſpoſ'd; and has denied all viſits,
The maid I have in charge to receive from ye,
So pleaſe you render her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: With all my ſervice,
But faine I would have ſeene,

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: 'Tis but your patience;
No doubt ſhe cannot but remember nobely.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Theſe three yeares I have lov'd this ſcornfull Lady,
And followed her with all the truth of ſervice,
In all which time, but twice ſhe has honoured me
With ſight of her bleſt beauty: when you pleaſe Sir,
You may receive your charge, and tell your Lady;
A Gentleman whoſe life is onely dedicated,
To her commands, kiſſes her beauteous hands;
And Faire-one, now your helpe, you may remember
The honeſt courteſies, ſince you are mine
I ever did your modeſty: you ſhall be neare her,
And if ſometimes you name my ſervice to her
And tell her with what nobleneſſe I love her,
'Twill be a gratitude I ſhall remember.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: What in my poore power lyes, ſo it be honeſt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I aske no more.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: You muſt along with me (Faire)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And ſo I leave you two: but to a fortune
Too happy for my fate: you ſhall enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Be quick, be quick, Out with the bucket there,
Theſe ſents are dull; caſt richer on, and fuller;
Sente every place, where have you plas'd the muſicke?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Here they ſtand ready Sir.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: 'Tis well, be ſure
The wines be luſty, high, and full of ſpirit,
And Amberd all.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: They are

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Give faire attendance.
In the beſt trim, and ſtate, make ready all. Banquet ſet forth Exit.
I ſhall come preſently againe.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: We ſhall Sir,
What preperation's this?
Some new deviſe
My Lady has in hand,

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: ô, proſper it
As long as it carries good wine in the mouth?
And good meate with it, where are all the reſt

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: They are ready to attend.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sure ſome great perſon, Muſicke
They would not make this hurry elſe.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: Harke the Muſicke.
It will appeare now certaine, here it comes.
Now to our places.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Whether will he lead me?
What invitations this? to what new end,
Are theſe faire preperations? a rich Banquet,
Muſicke, and every place ſtuck with adornment,
Fit for a Princes welcome; what new game
Has Fortune now prepared to ſhew me happie?
And then againe to ſink me? 'tis no illuſion.
Mine eyes are not deceiv'd, all theſe are reall;
What wealth and State?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Will you ſit downe and eate Sir?
Theſe carry little wonder, they are uſuall;
But you ſhall ſee, if you be wiſe to obſerve it,
That that will ſtrike indeed: ſtrike with amazement,
Then if you be a man: this faire health to you.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What ſhall I ſee? I pledge ye Sir, I was never
So buried in amazement—

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You are ſo ſtill
Drinke freely.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The very wines are admirable:
Good Sir, give me leave to aske this queſtion,
For what great worthy man, are theſe prepard?
And why do you bring me hither?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: They are for you, Sir;
And under-vallve not the worth you carry,
You are that worthy man: thinke well of theſe.
They ſhall be more, and greater.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Well, blinde fortune
Thou haſt the prettieſt changes when thou art pleas'd,
To play thy game out wantonly—

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Come be luſty
And awake your Spirits. Ceaſe Muſick

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Good Sir, do not wake me.
For willingly I would dye in this dreame, pray whoſe Servants
Are all theſe that attend her?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: They are yours;
They wait on you,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I never yet remember
I kept ſuch faces, nor that I was ever able
To maintaine ſo many.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Now you are, and ſhall be,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You'l ſay this houſe is mine too?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Say it? ſweare it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: And all this wealth?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: This is the leaſt you ſee Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Why, where has this been hid theſe thirtie yeares?
For certainely I never found I was wealthie
Till this hower, never dream'd of houſe, and Servants,
I had thought I had been a younger brother, a poore Gent.
I may eat boldly then.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: 'Tis prepared for ye.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The taſte is perfect, and moſt delicate:
But why for me? give me ſome wine, I do drink;
I feele it ſenſibly, and I am here,
Here in this glorious place: I am bravely uſed too,
Good Gentle Sir, give me leave to thinke a little
For either I am much abus'd—

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Strike Muſick
And ſing that luſty Song. Muſick Song.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Bewitching harmony!
Sure I am turn'd into another Creature.
Happy and bleſt, Arnoldo was unfortunate;
Ha? bleſſe mine eyes; what pretious piece of nature
To poze the world?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I told you, you would ſee that,
Would darken theſe poore preparations;
What think ye now? nay riſe not, 'tis no viſion.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Tis more: 'tis miracle.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: You are welcome Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: It ſpeakes, and entertaines me ſtill more glorious;
She is warme, and this is fleſh here: how ſhe ſtirrs me.
Bleſſe me what ſtars are there?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: May I ſit neere ye?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No, you are too pure an object to behold,
Too excellent to looke upon, and live;
I muſt remove.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: She is a woman Sir,
Fy, what faint hart is this

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The houſe of wonder.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Do not you thinke your ſelfe now truely happie?
You have the abſtract of all ſweetneſſe by ye,
The pretious wealth youth Labors to arrive at
Nor is ſhe leſſe in honour, then in beauty,
Ferraras, roiall Duke, is proud to call her
His be●t, his nobleſt, and moſt happie Siſter,
Fortune has made her Miſtris of herſelfe,
Wealthy, and wiſe, without a power to ſway her,
Wonder of Italy, of all harts Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: And all this is—

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Hyppolita the beauteous.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: You are a poore relator of my fortunes,
Too weake a Chronicle to ſpeak my bleſſings,
And leave out that eſſentiall part of Story
I am moſt high and happy in, moſt fortunate,
The acquaintance, and the noble fellowſhip
Of this faire Gentleman: pray ye do not wonder,
Nor hold it ſtrange to heare a handſome Lady
Speak freely to ye: with your fair leave & courteſie
I will ſit by ye.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I know not what to anſwer,
Nor where I am, nor to what end conſider;
Why do you uſe me thus?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: are ye angry Sir,
Becauſe ye are entertain'd with all humanity?
Freely and nobly us'd?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: No gentle Lady
That were uncivill, but it much amazes me
A ſtranger, and a man of no deſert
Should finde ſuch floods of courteſie.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I love ye,
I honour ye, the firſt and beſt of all men,
And where that faire opinion leads, 'tis uſuall
Theſe trifles that but ſerve to ſet off, follow,
I would not have you proud now, nor diſdainful
Becauſe I ſay I love ye, though I ſweare it,
Nor thinke it a ſtale favour I fling on ye,
Though ye be handſome, and the only man
I muſt confeſſe I ever fixt mine eye on,
And bring along all promiſes that pleaſe us,
Yet I ſhould hate ye then, deſpiſe ye, ſcorne ye,
And with as much contempt purſue your perſon,
As now I doe with love. But you are wiſer,
At leaſt I think, more maſter of your fortune,
And ſo I drink your health.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Hold faſt good honeſty,
I am a loſt man elſe.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Now you may kiſſe me,
'Tis the firſt kiſſe, I ever aske, I ſweare to ye.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: That I dare doe ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: You doe it well too;
You are a Maſter Sir, that makes you coy.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Would you would ſend your people off.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Well thought on.
Wait all without. Exit. Zab. and ſervants

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I hope ſhe is pleaſ'd throughly.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Why ſtand ye ſtill? her'es no man to detect ye,
My people are gon off: come, come, leave conjuring
The Spirit you would raiſe, is here already
Looke boldly on me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What would you have me doe?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: O moſt unmanly queſtion! have you do?
Is't poſſible your yeares ſhould want a Tutor?
I'le teach ye: come, embrace me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Fy ſtand off;
And give me leave, more now, then ere, to wonder,
A building of ſo goodly a proportion,
Outwardly all exact, the frame of Heaven,
Should hide within ſo baſe Inhabitants?
You are as faire, as if the morning bare ye,
Imagination never made a ſweeter;
Can it be poſſible this frame ſhould ſuffer,
And built on ſlight affections, fright the vewer?
Be excellent in all, as you are outward,
The worthy Miſtris of thoſe many bleſſings
Heaven has beſtowed, make 'em appeare ſtill nobler,
Becauſe they are truſted to a weaker keeper.
Would ye have me love ye?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Yes,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Not for your beautie;
Though I confeſſe, it blowes the firſt fire in us,
Time as he paſſes by, puts out that ſparkle,
Nor for your wealth, although the world kneele to it,
And make it all addition to a woman,
Fortune that ruines all, makes that his conqueſt;
Be honeſt, and be vertuous, i'le admire ye,
At leaſt be wiſe, and where ye lay theſe nets,
Strow over 'em a little modeſty,
'Twill well become your cauſe, and catch more Fooles.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Could any one that lov'd this wholſome counſell
But love the giver more? you make me fonder:
You have a vertuous minde, I want that ornament;
Is it a ſin I covet to enjoy ye?
If ye imagine I am too free a Lover,
And act that part belongs to you I am ſilent;
Mine eyes ſhall ſpeake my bluſhes, parly with ye,
I will not touch your hand, but with a tremble
Fitting a veſtall Nun; not long to kiſſe ye,
But gently as the aire, and undiſcerned too,
I'le ſteale it thus: I'le walke your ſhadow by ye,
So ſtill and ſilent that it ſhall be equall,
To put me off, as that, and when I covet,
To give ſuch toyes as theſe —

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: A new temptation—

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Thus like the lazie minuts will I drop 'em,
Which paſt once are forgotten.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Excellent vice!

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Will ye be won? looke ſtedfaſtly upon me,
Looke manly, take a mans affections to you;
Young women, in the old world were not wont, Sir,
To hang out gaudy busſhes for their beauties,
To talke themſelues into young-mens affections;
How cold and dull you are?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How I ſtagger?
She is wiſe, as faire; but 'tis a wicked wiſedome;
I'le choake before I yield.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: who waites within there Zabulon within.
Make ready the greene chamber,

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: It ſhall be Madam.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am afraid ſhe will injoy me indeed,

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: What Muſicke do ye love?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: A modeſt tongue.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Wee'll have enough of that: fy, fy, how lumpiſh?
In a young Ladies armes, thus dull?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: For heaven ſake
Profeſs a little goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Of what Countrey?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am of Rome.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Nay then I know you mock me,
The Italians are not frighted with ſuch bug-bears,
Prethee go in.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am not well;

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I'le make thee,
I'le kiſſe thee well:

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am not ſicke of that ſore.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: upon my conſcience, I muſt raviſh thee,
I ſhall be famous for the firſt example:
With this I'le tye ye firſt, then trye your ſtrength Sir,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: My ſtrength, away baſe woman? I abhor thee.
I am not caught with ſtales, diſeaſe dwell with thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Are ye ſo quicke? and have I loſt my wiſhes?
Hoe, Zabulon; my Seruants.
Call'd ye Madam?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Is all that beautie ſcorned, ſo many ſude for?
So many Princes? by a ſtranger too?
Muſt I endure this?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Wher's the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Go preſently, purſue the ſtranger, Zabulon.
He has broke from me, Jewels I have given him:
Charge him with theft: hee has ſtolne my love, my free|dome,
Draw him before the Governour, impriſon him,
Why doſt thou ſtay?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I'le teach him a new daunce,
For playing faſt and looſe with ſuch a Lady.
Come fellowes, come: I'le execute your anger,
And to the full.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: His ſcorne ſhall feele my vengeance.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Shall I never ſee a luſty man againe?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Faith Miſtris
You do ſo over-labour 'em when you have 'em,
And ſo dry-founder 'em, they cannot laſt.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Wher's the French-man?
Alas, he's all to fitters,
And lyes, taking the height of his fortune with a Sirreng.
Hee's chin'd, he's chin'd good man, he is a mourner.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: What's become of the Dane?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Who? goldy-locks?
Hee's foule i'th touch-hole; and recoiles againe,
The main Spring's weakned that holds up his cock,
He lies at the ſigne of the Sun, to be new breech'd.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: The Rutter too, is gone.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: O that was a brave raſcall,
He would labour like a threſher: but alas
What thing can ever laſt? he has been ill mewd,
And drawne too ſoon; I have ſeene him in the Hoſpitall.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: There was an Engliſh-man.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I there was an Engliſh-man;
You'le ſcant finde any now, to make that name good.
There was thoſe Engliſh that were men indeed,
And would performe like men, but now they are vaniſht:
They are ſo taken up in their own Countrey,
And ſo beaten off their ſpeed, by their own women,
When they come here, they draw their legs like hackneys:
Drinke, and their owne devices has undone 'em.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: I muſt have one that's ſtrong, no life in Lisbon elſe,
Perfect and young: my cuſtome with young Ladies,
And high-fed Citie dames, will fall, and breake elſe.
I want my ſelfe too, in mine age to nouriſh me:
They are are all ſunk I maintain'd: now what's this buſi|neſſe.
What goodly fellow's that?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Why do you drag me?
Pox ô your Juſtice; let me looſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: Not ſo Sir.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Cannot a man fall into one of your drunken Cel|lers,
And ventur the breaking on's neck, your trap-dores open
But he muſt be us'd thus raſcally?

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: What made you wandring
So late i'th night? you know that is impriſonment.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: May be I walke in my ſleep.

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.l: May be wee'l walk ye.
What made ye wandring Sir, into that vault
Where all the Citie ſtore, and the Munition lay?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I fell into't by chance, I broke my ſhins for't.
Your Worſhips feele not that: I knockt my head
Againſt a hundred poſts, would you had had it.
Cannot I breake my necke in mine own defence?

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.l: This will not ſerve: you cannot put it off ſo,
Your comming thither was to play the villaine,
To fire the powder, to blow that part oth' City.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Yes, with my noſe: why were the trap-doors open?
Might not you fall, or you? had you gone that way?
I thought your Citie had ſunke.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: You did your beſt Sir,
We muſt preſume to help it into'th aire.
If you call that ſinking: we have told you what's the law,
He that is taken there, unleſſe a Magiſtrate,
And have command in that place, preſently
If there be nothing found apparent, neare him
Worthie his torture, or his preſent death,
Muſt either pay his fine for his preſumption,
(Which is ſixe hundred Duckets) or for ſix yeares
Tug at an Oare i'th Gallies: will ye walke Sir,
For we preſume you cannot pay the penalty.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Row in the Gallies, after all this miſchief?

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.l: May be you were drunke, they'le keepe you ſober there.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Tug at an Oare? you are not arrant raſcals,
To catch me in a pit-fall, and betray me,

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: A luſty minded man.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: A wondrous able.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Pray Gentlemen, allow me but that liberty
To ſpeake a few words with your priſoner
And I ſhall thanke you.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: Take your pleaſure, Lady.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: What would you give that woman ſhould redeem ye,
Redeem ye from this ſlavery?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Beſides my ſervice
I would give her my whole ſelfe, I would be her vaſſall.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Shee has reaſon to expect as much, conſidering
The great ſumme ſhe payes for't, yet take comfort
What ye ſhall doe to merit this, is eaſie
And I will be the woman ſhall befriend ye,
'Tis but to entertaine ſome handſome Ladies,
And young faire Gentlewomen: you gheſſe the way:
But giving of your mind—

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I am excellent at it:
You cannot picke out ſuch another living.
I underſtand ye: is't not thus?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Ye have it.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Bring me a hundred of em: I'le diſpatch 'em,
I will be none but yours: ſhould another offer
Another way to redeem me, I ſhould ſcorne it.
What women you ſhall pleaſe: I am monſtrous luſty:
Not to be taken downe: would you have Children?
I'le get you thoſe as faſt, and thicke as flie-blows.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: I admire him: wonder at him.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Harke ye Lady,
You may require ſometimes—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: I by my faith.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And you ſhall have it by my faith, & handſomly:
This old Cat wil ſuck ſhrewdly: you have no daughters?
I flye at all: now am I in my Kingdome,
Tug at an Oare? no, tug in a feather-bed,
With good warme Candles; hang your bread and water,
I'le make you young againe, beleeve that Lady.
I will ſo frubbiſh you.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Come, follow Officers,
This Gentleman is free: I'le pay the Duckets.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And when you catch me in your City-powdring-tub
Againe, boile me with Cabbidge.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: You are both warn'd and arm'd Sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Will your Ladiſhip weare this dreſſing?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Leave thy prating:
I care not what I weare.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Yet 'tis my duty
To know your pleaſure, and my worſt affection
To ſee you diſcontented.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Weeping too?
Prethee forgive me: I am much diſtemperd,
And ſpeake I know not what: to make thee amends
The gowne that I wore yeſterday, is thine;
Let it alone a while.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now you perceive,
And taſte her bounty.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Much above my merit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But have you not yet found a happy time
To move for me.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I have watched all occaſions,
But hitherto, without ſucceſſe: yet doubt not
But I'le embrace the firſt meanes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Do, and proſper;
Excellent creature, whoſe perfections make
Even ſorrow lovely, if your frowns thus take me
What would your ſmiles doe?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Pox ô this ſtale Courtſhip:
If I have any power.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am commanded,
Obedience is the Lovers ſacrifice
Which I pay gladly.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: To be forc'd to wooe,
Being a woman, could not but torment me,
But bringing for my Advocates, youth and beauty,
Set off with wealth: and then to be deni'd too
Do's comprehend all tortures. They flatterd me,
That ſaid my lookes were charmes, my touches fetters,
My locks ſoft chaines, to binde the armes of Princes,
And make them in that wiſh'd for bondage, happy,
I am like others of a courſer feature,
As weake to allure, but in my dotage, ſtronger:
I am no Circe; he, more then Ʋlyſſes,
Scornes all my offerd bounties, ſlights my favours,
And, as I were ſome new Egyptian, flyes me,
Leaving no pawne, but my own ſhame behind him.
But he ſhall finde, that in my fell revenge,
I am a woman: one that never pardons
The rude contemner of her profferd ſweetneſſe.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis done;

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: What's done?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: The uncivill ſtranger
Is at your ſuite arreſted.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: 'Tis well handled.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: And under guard ſent to the Governour,
With whom my teſtimony, and the favour,
He beares your Ladiſhip, have ſo prevail'd
That he is ſentenc'd.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: To looſe his head.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Is that the meanes to quench the ſcorching heate
Of my inrag'd deſires? muſt innocence ſuffer,
'Cauſe I am faulty? or is my Love ſo fatall
That of neceſſity it muſt deſtroy
The object it moſt longs for? dull Hypollita,
To thinke that injuries could make way for love,
When courteſies were deſpis'd: that by his death
Thou ſhouldſt give that, which only thou canſt hope for
While he is living: My honours at the ſtake now,
And cannot be preſerv'd, unleſſe he periſh
The enjoying of the thing I love, I ever
Have priz'd above my fame: why doubt I now then?
One only way is left me, to redeeme all:
Make ready my Caroch.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What will you Madam.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: And yet I am impatient of ſuch ſtay:
Bind up my haire: fy, fy, while that is doing
The Law may ceaſe his life: thus, as I am then,
Not like Hypollita, but a Bachanall
My frantique Love tranſports me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sure ſhee's diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Pray you follow her: I will along with you:
I more then gheſſe the cauſe: women that love
Are moſt uncertaine, and one minute crave,
What, in another they refuſe to have. Exit.

div.head: Scaena 5^a.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Aſſure thy ſelfe Charino, I am alter'd
From what I was; the tempeſts we have met with
In our uncertaine voyage, were ſmooth gales
Compar'd to thoſe, the memory of my luſts
Raiſ'd in my conſcience: and if ere againe
I live to ſee Zenocia, I will ſue,
And ſeeek to her as a Lover, and a Servant,
And not command affection, like a Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: In hearing this; you make me young againe,
And heaven, it ſeemes, favouring this good change in you
In ſetting of a period to our dangers
Gives us faire hopes, to find that here in Lisbon
Which hitherto in vain we long have ſought for.
I have receiv'd aſſur'd intelligence;
Such ſtrangers have bin ſeen here: and though yet
I cannot learn their fortunes, nor the place
Of their abode, I have a ſoule preſages
A fortunate event here.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: There have paſs'd
A mutuall enterchange of courteſies
Between me, and the Governour; therfore boldly
We may preſume of him, and of his power
If we finde cauſe to uſe them, otherwiſe
I Would not be known here, and theſe diſguiſes
Will keep us from diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What are theſe?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: The Governour: with him my Rivall, bound.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: For certaine 'tis Arnoldo.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Let's attend
What the ſucceſſe will be.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Is't poſſible
There ſhould be hope of his recovery,
His wounds ſo many and ſo deadly?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: So they appear'd at firſt, but the blood ſtop'd,
His trance forſook him, and on better ſearch
We found they were not mortall;

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Uſe all care
To perfect this unhop'd for cure: that done
Propoſe your own rewards; and till you ſhall
Heare farther from me, for ſome ends I have,
Conceal'd it from his Mother.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Wee'l not faile Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You ſtil ſtand confident on your innocence.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: It is my beſt and laſt guard, which I will not
Leave, to relye on your uncertaine mercy.

div.stage: Enter Hypolita, Zabulon, Leopold, Zenocia, 2 Servants.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Who bade you follow me! Goe home, & you Sir,
As you reſpect me, goe with her.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: And in her houſe a Servant?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: 'Tis my daughter.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: My love? Contain your joy, obſerve the ſequel. Zen. paſſes

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Fye Madam, how undecent 'tis for you.
So far, unlike your ſelfe to bee ſeene thus
In th'open ſtreets? why do you kneele? pray you riſe,
I am acquainted with the wrong, and loſſe
You have ſuſtain'd, and the Delinquent now
Stands ready for his puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Let it fall Sir,
On the offender: he is innocent
And moſt unworthy of theſe bonds he weares,
But I made up of guilt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: VVhat ſtrange turne's this?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: This was my priſoner once.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: If chaſtity
In a young man, and tempted to the height too
Did ere deſerve reward, or admiration,
He juſtly may claim both. Love to his perſon
(Or if you pleaſe give it a fowler name)
Compel'd me firſt to train him to my houſe,
All engines I rais'd there to ſhake his vertue,
Which in the aſſault were uſeleſſe; he unmov'd ſtil
As if he had no part of humane frailty,
Againſt the nature of my Sex, almoſt
I plaid the Raviſher. You might have ſeen
In our contention, young Apollo fly
And love-ſicke Daphne follow, all arts failing,
By flight he wan the victory, breaking from
My ſcorn'd embraces: the repulſe (in women
Unſufferable) invited me to practiſe
A meanes to be reveng'd: and from this grew
His Accuſation, and the abuſe
Of your ſtill equall juſtice: My rage ever
Thanks heaven, though wanton, I found not my ſelfe
So far engag'd to hell, to proſecute
To the death what I had plotted, for that love
That made me firſt deſire him, then accuſe him,
Commands me with the hazard of my ſelfe
Firſt to entreate his pardon, then acquit him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What ere you are, ſo much I love your vertue
That I deſire your friendſhip: doe you unlooſe him
From thoſe bonds, you are worthy of, your repentance
Makes part of ſatisfaction; yet I muſt
Severely reprehend you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am made
A ſtale on all parts: But this fellow ſhall
Pay dearely for her favour.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: My life's ſo full
Of various changes, that I now deſpaire
