Of any certaine port; one trouble ending,
A new, and worſe ſucceeds it: what ſhould Zenocia
Doe in this womans houſe? Can chaſtity
And hot Luſt dwell together without infection?
I would not be or jealous, or ſecure,
Yet ſomething muſt be done, to ſound the depth on't:
That ſhe lives is my bliſſe, but living there,
A hell of torments; there's no way to her
In whom I live, but by this door, through which
To me, 'tis death to enter, yet I muſt,
And will make tryall.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Let me hear no more
Of theſe devices, Lady: this I pardon,
And at your interceſſion I forgive
Your inſtrument the Jew too: get you home.
The hundred thouſand crowns you lent the City
Towards the ſetting forth of the laſt Navy
Bound for the Iſlands, was a good then, which
I ballance with your ill now.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Now Sir, to him,
You know my daughter needs it.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Let me take
A farewell with mine ey, Sir, though my lip,
Be barr'd the Ceremonie, courteſie
And cuſtome too allowes of.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Gentle Madam,
I neither am ſo cold, nor ſo ill bred
But that I dare receive it: you are unguarded,
And let me tell you that I am aſham'd
Of my late rudeneſs, and would gladly therefore
If you pleaſe to accept my ready ſervice
Waite on you to your houſe.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Above my hope:
Sir, if an Angel were to be my convoy
He ſhould not be more welcome.— Exit Arn. and Hyp.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Now you know me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Yes Sir, and honour you: ever remembring
Your many bounties, being ambitious only
To give you cauſe to ſay by ſome one ſervice
That I am not ungratefull.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: 'Tis now offer'd:
I have a ſuite to you, and an eaſie one,
Which e're long you ſhall know.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: When you think fit Sir,
And then as a command; I will receive it,
Till when, moſt welcome: you are welcome too Sir,
'Tis ſpoken from the heart, and therefore needs not
Much proteſtation: at your better leyſure
I will enquire the cauſe that brought you hither:
In the meane time ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You out-doe me Sir. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Duart.
sp.l: You have beſtowed on me a ſecond life
For which I live your creature, and have better'd
What nature fram'd unperfect, my firſt being
Inſolent pride made monſtrous; but this later
In learning me to know my ſelfe, hath taught me
Not to wrong others.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Then we live indeed.
When we can goe to reſt without a larum
Given every minute to a guilt-ſick conſcience
To keep us waking, and riſe in the morning
Secure in being innocent: but when
In the remembrance of our worſer actions
We ever beare about us whips and furies,
To make the day a night of ſorrow to us,
Even life's a burthen.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I have found and felt it;
But will endeavour having firſt made peace
With thoſe inteſtine enemies my rude paſſions
To be ſo with man-kinde: but worthy Doctor,
Pray if you can reſolve me; was the Gentleman
That left me dead, ere brought unto his tryall?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Nor known, nor apprehended.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Thats my griefe.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Why doe you wiſh he had been puniſhed?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: No,
The ſtreame of my ſwoln ſorrow runs not that way:
For could I finde him, as I vow to heaven
It ſhall be my firſt care to ſeek him out,
I would with thankes acknowledge that his ſword,
In opening my veines, which proud bloud poiſon'd,
Gave the firſt ſymptomes of true health.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: 'Tis in you
A Chriſtian reſolution: that you live
Is by the Governours, your Uncles charge
As yet conceal'd. And though a ſons loſſe never
Was ſolemniz'd with more teares of true ſorrow
Then have been paid by your unequald Mother
For your ſuppoſed death, ſhee's not acquainted
With your recovery.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: For ſome few dayes
Pray let her ſo continue: thus diſguis'd
I may abroad unknown.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Without ſuſpition
Of being diſcovered

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I am confident
No moiſture ſooner dies then womens teares,
And therefore though I know my Mother vertuous,
Yet being one of that fraile ſex I purpoſe
Her farther tryall.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: That as you thinke fit—I'le not betray you

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: To finde out this ſtranger
This true Phiſician of my mind and manners
Were ſuch a bleſſing. He ſeem'd poore, and may
Perhaps be now in want; would I could finde him.
The Innes I'le ſearch firſt, then the publique Stewes
He was of Italy, and that Countrey breeds not
Preciſians that way, but hot Libertines;
And ſuch the moſt are: 'tis but a little travaile:
I am unfurniſht too, pray Mr. Doctor,
Can you ſupply me?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: With what ſumme you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I will not be long abſent.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: That I wiſh too;
For till you have more ſtrength, I would not have you
To be too bold.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Feare not, I will be carefull. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I have brought him Sir, a fellow that will do it
Though Hell ſtood in his way, ever provided
You pay him for't.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: He had a ſtrange aſpect
And lookes much like the figure of a hang-man
In a table of the Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: He tranſcends,
All preſidents beleeve it, a fleſh'd ruffian,
That hath ſo often taken the Strappado,
That 'tis to him, but as a lofty tricke
Is to a tumbler: he hath peruſed too,
All Dungeons in Portugall, thrice ſeven yeares
Rowed in the Galleys for three ſeverall murthers,
Though I preſume that he has done a hundred,
And ſcapt unpuniſht.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: He is much indebt to you,
You ſet him off ſo well. What will you take Sir
To beate a fellow for me, that thus wrongd me?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: To beate him ſay you?

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Yea, beate him to lameneſſe,
To cut his lips or noſe off; any thing,
That may disfigure him.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Let me conſider?
Five hundred piſtollets for ſuch a ſervice
I thinke were no deare penniworth.

sp.speaker: Z●b.
sp.l: Five hundred!
Why there are of your brother-hood in the Citie,
Ile undertake ſhall kill a man for twenty.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Kill him? I think ſo; Ile kill any man
For halfe the money.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: And will you aske more
For a ſound beating then a murther?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I Sir,
And with good reaſon, for a dog that's dead
The Spaniſh proverb ſaies, will never bite:
But ſhould I beate or hurt him only, he may
Recover, and kill me.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: A good conclu●ion,
The obduracie of this raſcall makes me tender.
I'le runne ſome other courſe, there's your reward,
Without the employment.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: For that as you pleaſe Sir;
When you have need to kill a man, pray uſe me,
But I am out at beating. Exit.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: What's to be done then?

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: I'le tell thee Zabulon, and make thee privy
To my moſt neare deſignes: this ſtranger, which
Hyppolita ſo doates on, was my priſoner
When the laſt Virgin, I beſtowed upon her,
Was made my prize? how he eſcap'd, hereafter
J'le let thee know; and it may be the love
He beares the ſervant, makes him ſcorne the Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: 'Tis not unlike; for the firſt time he ſaw her
His lookes expreſt ſo much, and for more proofe
Since he came to my Ladies houſe, though yet
He never knew her, he hath practi●'d with me
To help him to a conference, without
The knowledge of Hyppolita; which I promis'd.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: And by all meanes performe it, for their meeting,
But worke it ſo, that my diſdainfull Miſtris
(Whom, notwithſtanding all he● injuries
'Tis my hard fate to love) may ſee and heare them.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: To what end Sir?

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: This Zabulon: when ſhe ſees
Who is her rivall, and her Lovers baſeneſſe
To leave a Princeſſe for her bondwoman,
The ſight make her ſcorne, what now ſhe doates on,
I'le double thy reward.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You are like to ſpeed then:
For I confeſſe what you will ſoone beleeve,
We ſerve them beſt that are moſt apt to give.
For you I'le place you where you ſhall ſee all, and yet be unobſerv'd.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Tat I deſire too. Exit.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I cannot ſee her yet, how it afflicts me:
The poyſon of this place, ſhould mixe it ſelfe
With her pure thoughts? 'Twas ſhe that was commanded
Or my eyes failed me groſly; that youth, that face
And all that noble ſweetneſſe. May ſhee not live here,
And yet be honeſt ſtill?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: It is Arnoldo,
From all his dangers free; fortune I bleſſe thee,
My noble husband! how my joy ſwells in me,
But why in this place? what buſineſſe hath he here?
He cannot heare of me, I am not known here.
I left him vertuous; how I ſhake to thinke now?
And how that joy I had, cooles, and forſakes me?
This Lady is but faire, I have beene thought ſo
Without compare admired; Shee has bewitched him
And he forgot—

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.p: 'Tis ſhe againe, the ſame—the ſame Zenocia.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: There they are together. — Now you may mark

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Peace let 'em parly.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: That you are well Zenocia; and once more,
Bleſſe my deſpairing eyes, with your wiſht preſence,
I thanke the gods; but that I meete you here—

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: They are acquainted,

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I found that ſecret Madam,
When you commanded her goe home: pray heare 'em.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: That you meet me here, ne're bluſh at that Arnoldo.
Your comming comes too late: I am a woman,
And one woman with another may be truſted;
Do you feare the houſe?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: More then a feare, I know●t,
Know it not good, not honeſt.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: What do you here then?
I'th name of vertue why doe you approach it?
Will you confeſſe the doubt and yet purſue it?
Where have your eyes been wandring my Arnoldo?
What conſtancy, what faith do you call this? Fie,
Aime at one wanton marke, and wound another?
I doe confeſſe, the Lady faire, moſt beauteous, Leopold places him|ſelf unſeen below.
And able to betray a ſtrong mans liberty,
But you that have a love, a wife—you do well
To deale thus wiſely with me: yet Arnoldo,
Since you are pleas'd to ſtudie a new beauty,
And think this old and ill, beaten with miſery.
Studie a nobler way for ſhame to love me,
Wrong not her honeſty.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You have confirm'd me.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Who though ſhee be your wife, will never hinder you,
So much I reſt a ſervant to your wiſhes,
And love your Loves, though they be my deſtructions,
No man ſhall know me, nor the ſhare I have in thee,
No eye ſuſpect, I am able to prevent you,
For ſince I am a ſlave to this great Lady,
Whom I perceive you follow

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Be not blinded.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Fortune ſhall make me uſeful to your ſervice,
I will ſpeake for you.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Speake for me? you wrong me.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I will endeavour all the wayes I am able
To make her think well of you; will that pleaſe,
To make her dote upon you, dote to madneſſe,
So far againſt my ſelfe I will obey you.
But when that's done, and I have ſhewed this duty
This great obedience, few will buy it at my price,
Thus will I ſhake hands with you, wiſh you well,
But never ſee you more, nor receive comfort
From any thing, Arnoldo.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You are too tender;
I neither doubt you, nor deſire longer
To be a man, and live, then I am honeſt
And only yours; our infinite affections
Abus'd us both.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Where are your favours now?
The courteſies you ſhew'd this ſtranger, Madam?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Have I now found the cauſe?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Attend it further.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Did ſhe invite you doe you ſay?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Moſt cunningly,
And with a preparation of that ſtate
I was brought in and welcom'd.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Seem'd to love you?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Moſt infinitly, at firſt ſight, moſt dotingly.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Shee is a goodly Lady;

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Wondrous handſome:
At firſt view, being taken unprepar'd,
Your memory, not preſent then to aſſiſt me,
Shee ſeem'd ſo glorious ſweet, and ſo far ſtird me,
Nay be not jealous, there's no harme done.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Prethee—didſt thou not kiſſe Arnoldo?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Yes faith did I.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: And then—

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I durſt not, did not—

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I forgive you,
Come tell the truth.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: May be I lay with her.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: He mocks me too, moſt baſely.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Did yee faith? did ye forget ſo far?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Come, come, no weeping;
I would have lyen firſt in my grave, beleeve that.
Why will you aske thoſe things you would not heare?
Shee is too untemperate to betray my vertues
Too openly laſcivious: had ſhe dealt
But with that ſeeming modeſty ſhe might,
And flung a little Art upon her ardor,
But 'twas forgot, and I forgot to like her,
And glad I was deceiv'd. No my Zenocia,
My firſt love here begun, reſts here unreapt yet,
And here for ever.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: You have made me happy,
Even in the midſt of bondage bleſt.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You ſee now
What rubs are in your way.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: And quickly Zabulon
I'le roote 'em out.—Be ſure you do this preſently.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Doe not you alter then.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: I am reſolute. Exit Zab.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: To ſee you only I came hither laſt,
Drawne by no love of hers, nor baſe allurements,
For by this holy light I hate her heartily.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: I am glad of that you have ſav'd me ſo much vengeance
And ſo much feare
From this hour, faire befall you.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Some meanes I ſhall make ſhortly to redeem you,
Till when, obſerve her well, and fit her temper,
Only her luſt contemn.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: When ſhal I ſee you?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I will live here abouts, and bear her faire ſtil,
Till I can finde a fit houre to redeeme you.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Shut all the dores;

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: We are betray'd,
The Lady of the houſe has heard our parley,
Seene us, and ſeen our Loves.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: You courteous Gallant,
You that ſcorn all I can beſtow, that laugh at
The afflictions, and the grones I ſuffer for you,
That ſlight and jeere my love, contemn the fortune,
My favours can fling on you, have I caught you?
Have I now found the cauſe? yee foole my wiſhes?
Is mine own ſlave, my bane? I nouriſh that
That ſucks up my content. I'le pray, no more,
Nor wooe no more; thou ſhalt ſee fooliſh man,
And to thy bitter paine and anguiſh, looke on
The vengeance I ſhall take, provok'd and ſleighted;
Redeem her then, and ſteale her hence: ho Zabulon
Now to your worke.

div.stage: Enter Zabulon and ſervants, ſome holding Arnoldo, ſome ready with a cord to ſtrangle Zenocia.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Lady, but heare me ſpeake firſt,
As you have pitty.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I have none. You taught me,
When I even hung about your necke, you ſcorn'd me.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Shall we pluck yet?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: No, hold a little Zabulon,
I'le pluck his heart-ſtrings firſt: now am I worthy
A little of your love?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I'le be your ſervant,
Command me through what danger you ſhall aime at,
Let it be death.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Be ſure Sir, I ſhall fit you.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: But ſpare this Virgin;

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I would ſpare that villain firſt,
Had cut my Fathers throate.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Bounteous Lady,
If in your ſexe there be that noble ſoftneſſe,
That tenderneſſe of heart, women are crown'd for—

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Kneele not Arnoldo, doe her not that honour,
She is not worthy ſuch ſubmiſſion,
I ſcorne a life depends upon her pitty.
Proud woman do thy worſt, and arme thy anger,
With thoughts as blacke as hell, as hot and bloody,
I bring a patience here, ſhall make 'em bluſh,
An innocence, ſhall outlook thee, and death too.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Make me your ſlave, I give my freedome to ye,
For ever to be fetterd to your ſervice;
'Twas I offended, be not ſo unjuſt then,
To ſtrike the innocent, this gentle maid,
Never intended feare and doubt againſt you:
Shee is your ſervant, pay not her obſervance
With cruell looks, her duteous faith with death.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Am I faire now? now am I worth your liking?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Not faire, not to be liked, thou glorious Divell,
Thou verniſht piece of luſt, thou painted fury.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Speake gently ſweet, ſpeak gently;

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I'le ſpeak nobly.
'Tis not the ſaving of a life I aime at,
Marke me laſcivious woman, mark me truly,
And then conſider, how I weigh thy angers.
Life is no longer mine, nor deare unto me,
Then uſefull to his honour, I preſerve it
If thou hadſt ſtudied all the courteſies
Humanity and noble blood, ar linkt too,
Thou couldſt not have propounded ſuch a benefit,
Nor heapt upon me ſuch unlookt for honour
As dying for his ſake, to be his Martyr,
'Tis ſuch a grace.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: You ſhall not want that favour,
Let your bones worke miracles.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Dear Lady
By thoſe faire eyes—

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: There is but this way left ye
To ſave her life.—

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Speake it, and I embrace it.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Come to my private chamber preſently
And there, what love and I command—

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I'le doe it,
Be comforted Zenocia.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Do not do this,
To ſave me, do not looſe your ſelfe I charge you,
I charge you by your love, that love you beare me;
That love, that conſtant love you have twin'd to me,
By all your promiſes, take heed you keep 'em,
Now is your conſtant tryall. If thou doſt this,
Or mov'ſt one foote, to guide thee to her luſt,
My curſes and eternall hate purſue thee.
Redeem me at the baſe price of diſloyalty?
Muſt my undoubted honeſty be thy bawd too?
Goe and intwine thy ſelfe about that body?
Tell her, for my life thou haſt loſt thine honour,
Pulld all thy vowes from heaven, baſely, moſt baſely
To add an hour to me that hate thee for it,
Stoop'd to the ſervile flames of that foule woman
Know thee againe, nor name thee for a husband.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: What ſhall I doe to ſave her?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: How now, what haſt there?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Governour, attended with ſome Gentlemen,
Are newly entered, to ſpeake with your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Poxe ô their buſineſſe, reprieve her for this hour,
I ſhall have other time.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Now fortune help us.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: I'le meete 'em preſently: retire a while all. Exit.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You riſe to day upon your right ſide Lady;
You know the danger too, and may prevent it,
And if you ſuffer her to periſh thus,
As ſhe muſt doe, and ſuddenly beleeve it,
Unleſſe you ſtand her friend; you know the way on't,
I gheſſe you poorely love her, leſſe your fortune.
Let her know nothing, and performe this matter,
There are hours ordained for ſeverall buſineſſes,
You underſtand.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I underſtand you bawd Sir,
And ſuch a Councellour I never car'd for.

div.stage: Enter the Governour, Clodio, Leopold, Charino and Attendants at one doore, Hyppolita at the other.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip does me honour.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Faire Hyppolita,
I am come to eaſe you of a charge.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I keepe none,
I count a burthen Sir: and yet I lye too.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Which is the maide; is ſhe here?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Yes Sir,
This is ſhe, this is Zenocia,
The very ſame I ſued to your Lordſhip for.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Clodio againe? more miſery? more ruine?
Under what angry ſtarre is my life govern'd.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Come hither maid, you are once more a free wo' man
Here I diſcharge your bonds.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Another ſmile,
Another tricke of fortune to betray us!

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Why do's your Lordſhip uſe me ſo unnobly?
Againſt my will, to take away my bond-woman?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: She was no lawfull prize, therefore no bond-wo|man:
She's of that Countrey we hold friendſhip with,
And ever did, and therefore to be uſed
With entertainment, faire and courteous.
The breach of league in us gives foule example,
Therefore you muſt be pleas'd to think this honeſt;
Did you know what ſhe was?

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: Not till this inſtant;
For had I known her, ſhe had been no priſoner.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: There, take the maid, ſhe is at her owne diſpoſe now,
And if there be ought elſe to do your honour
Any poore ſervice in—

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I am vowed your ſervant;

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Your Father's here too, that's our only comfort,
And in a Countrey now, we ſtand free people,
Where Clodio has no power, be comforted.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I feare ſome trick yet.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Be not ſo dejected.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: You muſt not be diſpleas'd; ſo farewell Lady.
Come Gentlemen; Captain, you muſt with me too,
I have a little buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: I attend your Lordſhip:
Now my way's free, and my hopes. Lords againe.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Dy'e jeere me now ye are going?
I may live yet — to make you howle both.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You might have done; you had power then,
But now the chaines are off, the command loſt,
And ſuch a ſtory they will make of this
To laugh out lazie time.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: No meanes yet left me?
For now I burſt with anger: none to ſatisfie me?
No comfort? no revenge?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You ſpeake too late;
You might have had all theſe, your uſefull ſervants
Had you been wiſe, and ſuddain; What power, or will
Over her beauty, have you now? by violence
To conſtrain his love; ſhe is as free as you are,
And no law can impeach her liberty,
And whilſt ſhe is ſo, Arnoldo will deſpiſe you.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Either my love or anger muſt be ſatisfied,
Or I muſt dye.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I have a way woo'd do it,
Woo'd do it yet, protect me from the Law.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: From any thing; thou knoweſt what power I have
What money, and what friends.

sp.speaker: Zab
sp.l: 'Tis a divelliſh one:
But ſuch muſt now be us'd: walke in, I'le tell you;
And if you like it, if the Divell can doe any thing.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Divell, or what thou wilt, ſo I be ſatisfied. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: This is the rareſt, and the luſtieſt fellow,
And ſo beſtirs himſelfe—

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Give him breath Miſtris
You'l melt him elſe.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: He does perform ſuch wonders—
The women are mad on him.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Give him breath I ſay;
The man is but a man, he muſt have breath.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: How many had he yeſterday?
And they paid bravely too.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: About fourteene.
But ſtill I cry give breath, ſpare him and have him.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Five Dames to day; this was a ſmall ſtage
He may endure five more.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Breath, breath I cry ſtill;
Body ô me give breath, the man's a loſt man elſe.
Feede him and give him breath. Enter 2. Gentlewomen

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Welcome Gentlewomen,
Y'are very welcome.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: We heare you have a luſty & wel-complexion'd fellow
That does rare tricks, my ſiſter and my ſelfe here,
Would trifle out an houre or two ſo, pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Jaques, conduct 'em in.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: There's for your courteſie. Exeunt Jaqu. and Gent.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Good pay ſtil, good round pay, this happy fellow
Will ſet me up againe; he brings in gold
Faſter then I have leiſure to receive it.
O that his body were not fleſh and fading;
But I'le ſo papp him up —nothing too deare for him;
What a ſweee ſent he has?—Now what newes Jaques?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: He cannot laſt, I pitty the poor man
I ſuffer for him; two coaches of young City dames,
And they drive as the Divell were in the wheeles,
Are ready now to enter: and behind theſe
An old dead-palſied Lady in a litter,
And ſhe makes all the haſt ſhe can: the man's loſt,
You may gather up his dry bones to make nine-pins,
But for his fleſh.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Theſe are but eaſie labours,
Yet, for I know he muſt have reſt.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: He muſt:—you'l beate him off his leggs elſe pre|ſently.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Goe in, and bid him pleaſe himſelfe, I am pleas'd too:
To morrow's a new day; but if he can
I would have him take pity ô the old Lady.
Alas 'tis charity.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I'le tell him all this
And if he be not too fool-hardy.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: How now?
What newes with you?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You muſt preſently
Shew all the art you have, and for my Lady.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: She may command.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: You muſt not dream nor trifle.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Which way?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: A ſpell you muſt prepare, a powerfull one,
Peruſe but theſe directions, you ſhall find all;
There is the picture too, be quicke, and Faithfull,
And do it with that ſtrength—When 'tis perform'd
Pitch your reward at what you pleaſe, you have it.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Ile do my beſt, and ſuddainly: but hark ye,
Will you never lye at home againe?

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Excuſe me,
I have too much buſineſſe yet.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: I am right glad on't.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Think on your buſineſſe, ſo farewell.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: I'le do it.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Within this houre I'le viſit you againe
And give you greater lights.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: I ſhall obſerve ye;
This brings a brave reward, bravely I'le do it
And all the hidden art I have, expreſs in't. Ex. at both dores.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Now do I look as if I were Crow-trodden,
Fy how my hams ſhrinke under me; ô me,
I am broken-winded too; Is this a life?
Is this the recreation I have aimd at,
I had a body once, a handſome body,
And wholſome too. Now I appeare like a raſcall
That had been hung a yeare or two in gibbets.
Fye how I faint; Women? keep me from women;
Place me before a Cannon, 'tis a pleaſure;
Stretch me upon a rac it, a recreation;
But women? women? ô the Divell! women?
Curtius gulfe was never halfe ſo dangerous.
Is there no way to finde the trap-dore againe,
And fall into the Cellar, and be taken?
No lucky fortune to direct me that way?
No galleys to be got, nor yet no gallows?
For I feare nothing now, no earthly thing
But theſe unſatisfied Men-leeches, women.
How divelliſhly my bones ake: ô the old Lady!
I have a kind of waiting-woman, lyes croſſe my back too,
O how ſhe ſtings! no treaſon to deliver me?
Now what are you? do you mock me?
No Sir, no,
We were your Predeceſſors in this place,
And come to ſee you beare up.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Good Gentlemen;
You ſeem to have a ſnuffing in your head Sir,
A parlous ſnuffing, but this ſame dampiſh aire—
A dampiſh aire indeed.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Blow your face tenderly,
Your noſe will ne're endure it: mercy ô me,
What are men change'd to here? is my noſe faſt yet?
Mee thinks it ſhakes it'h hilts: pray tell me Gentlemen,
How long is't ſince you flouriſht here?
Not long ſince.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Move your ſelfe eaſily, I ſee you are tender,
Nor long endured.
The labour was ſo much Sir
And ſo few to perform it.—

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Muſt I come to this?
And draw my legs after me like a lame dog?
I cannot run away, I am too feeble:
Will you ſue for this place againe Gentlemen?

sp.p: No truly ſir, the place has been too warm for our com|plexions.

sp.l: We have enough on't, reſt you merry ſir,
We came but to congratulate your fortune,
You have abundance.
Beare your fortune ſoberly,
And ſo we leave you to the next faire Lady. Exit the 3.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Stay but a little, and I'le meet you Gentlemen,
At the next Hoſpitall: ther's no living thus,
Nor am I able to endure it longer,
With all the helps and heates that can be given me,
I am at my trot already; they are faire and young
Moſt of the women that repaire unto me,
But they ſtick on like burs, ſhake me like feathers.
More women yet?
Would I were honeſtly married,
To any thing that had but halfe a face,
And not a groate to keep her, nor a ſmocke,
That I might be civilly merry when I pleaſed,
Rather then labouring in theſe fulling mills.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: By this the ſpell begins to worke: you are luſty,
I ſee you beare up bravely yet.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Doe you heare Lady,
Do not make a game-beare of me, to play me hourly,
And fling on all your whelps; it will not hold;
Play me with ſome diſcretion; to day one courſe,
And two dayes hence another.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: If you be ſo angry
Pay backe the money I redeem'd you at
And take your courſe; I can have men enough:
You have loſt me an hundred crowns ſince you came hither,
In broths and ſtrengthning caudles; till you do pay m●
If you will eate and live, you ſhall endeavour,
I'le chain you to't elſe.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Make me a dog-ken〈…〉
I'le keep your houſe and bark, 〈◊〉●eed on bare bones,
And be whipt out a dores,
Doe you mark me Lady? whipt,
I'le eate old ſhoes. Enter Duart.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: In this houſe, I am told
There is a ſtranger, of a goodly perſon,
And ſuch a one there was; if I could ſee him,
I yet remember him.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Your buſineſſe Sir,
If it be for a woman, ye are cozend,
I keepe none here. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Certain this is the Gentleman,
The very ſame.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Death, if I had but money,
Or any friend to bring me from this bondage,
I would thraſh, ſet up a Coblers ſhop, keepe hogs,
And feede with 'em, ſell tinder boxes,
And Knights of Ginger-bread, thatch for three
Halfe pence a day, and thinke it Lordly,
From this baſe ſtallion trade: Why does he cy me,
Eye me ſo narrowly?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: It ſeemes you are troubled Sir,
I heard you ſpeak of want;

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: 'Tis better hearing
Far, then releiving Sir?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I do not think ſo, you know me not.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Not yet that I remember.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: You ſhall, and for your friend: I am beholding to yee
Greatly beholding Sir, If you remember,
You fought with ſuch a man, they cal'd Duart,
A proud diſtemper'd man: he was my enemie,
My mortall foe, you ſlew him fairly, nobly.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Speake ſoftly Sir, you do not meane to betray me
I wiſht the Gallows, now th'are comming fairely.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Be confident, for as I live, I love you,
And now you ſhall perceive it: for that ſervice
Me, and my purſe command: there, take it to ye,
'Tis gold, and no ſmall ſum, a thouſand duckets,
Supply your want.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: But do you do this faithfully?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: If I mean ill, ſpit in my face and kicke me,
In what elſe I may ſerve you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I thanke you,
This is as ſtrange to me as Knights adventure.
I have a project, 'tis an honeſt one,
And now I'le tempt my fortune.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Truſt me with it.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You are ſo good and honeſt I muſt truſt ye,
'Tis but to carry a letter to a Lady
That ſav'd my life once.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: That will be moſt thankfull,
I will do't with all care.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Where are you, white-broth?
Now luſty blood,
Come in, and tell your money:
'Tis ready here, no threats, nor no orations,
Nor prayers now.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: You do not meane to leave me—

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I'le live in hell ſooner then here, and cooler.
Come quickly come, diſpatch, this ayers unwholſome:
Quickly good Lady, quickly to't.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Well, ſince it muſt be,
The next, I'le fetter faſter ſure, and cloſer.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: And picke his bones, as y'are done mine, poxe take ye.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: At my lodging for a while, you ſhall be quarterd,
And there take phyſick for your health.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I thanke ye
I have found my Angel now too, if I can keepe him.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You like the Letter.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Yes, but I muſt tell you,
You tempt a deſperate hazard, to ſollicite
The mother, (and the grieved one too, 'tis rumord)
Of him you ſlew ſo lately.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I have told you
Some proofes of her affection, and I know not
A neerer way to make her ſatisfaction
For a loſt Sonne, then ſpeedily to help her
To a good husband; one that will beget
Both ſons and daughters, if ſhe be not barren.
I have had a breathing now, and have recovered
What I loſt in my late ſervice, 'twas a hot one:
It fir'd and fir'd me; but all thanks to you Sir,
You have both freed and cool'd me.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: What is done Sir
I thought well done, and was in that rewarded,
And therefore ſpare your thanks.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I'le no more whoring:
This fencing twixt a paire of ſheets, more weare● one
Then all the exerciſe in the world beſides.
To be drunk with good Canary, a meere Julip
Or like gourd-water to 't; twenty ſurfets
Come ſhort of one nights work there. If I get this Lady
As ten to one I ſhall; I was ne're denied yet,
I will live wondrous honeſtly; walk before her
Gravely, and demurely
And then inſtruct my family; you are ſad,
What do you muſe on Sir?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Truth I was thinking
What courſe to take for the delivery of your letter,
And now I have it: but faith did this Lady
(For do not gull your ſelfe) for certain know,
You kild her ſonne?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Give me a booke, I'le ſwear't;
Denyed me to the Officers, that purſued me,
Brought me her ſelfe to'th dore, then gave me gold
To beare my charges, and ſhall I make doubt then
But that ſhe lov'd me? I am confident
Time having tane her griefe off, that I ſhall be
Moſt welcome to her: for then to have wooed her
Had been unſeaſonable.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: well Sir, there's more money,
To make you handſome; I'le about your buſineſſe:
You know where you muſt ſtay.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: There you ſhall finde me:
Would I could meete my brother now, to know,
Whither the Jew, his Genius, or my Chriſtian,
Has prov'd the better friend. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: O who would truſt
Deceiving woman! or beleeve that one
The beſt, and moſt canoniz'd ever was
More then a ſeeming goodneſſe! I could raile now
Againſt the ſexe, and curſe it; but the theame
And way's too common: yet that Guiomar
My mother; (nor let that forbid her to be
The wonder of our nation) ſhe that was
Mark'd out the great example, for all Matrons
Both wife and Widow; ſhee that in my breeding
Expreſt the utmoſt of a mothers care,
And tenderneſſe to a ſonne; ſhe that yet faines
Such ſorrow for me; good God, that this mother,
After all this, ſhould give up to a ſtranger,
The wreake ſhe owed her ſonne; I feare her honour.
That he was ſav'd, much joyes me, and grieve only
That ſhe was his preſerver. I'le try further,
And by this Engine, find whether the teares,
Of which, ſhe is ſo prodigall, are for me,
Or us'd to cloake her baſe hypocriſy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Are you aſſur'd the charme prevailes?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Do I live?
Or you ſpeake to me? Now, this very inſtant
Health takes its laſt leave of her; maugre paleneſſe
Like winter, nips the Roſes and the lillies,
The Spring that youth, and love adorn'd her face with.
To force affection, is beyond our art,
For I have prov'd all meanes that hell has taught me,
Or the malice of a woman, which exceeds it,
To change Arnoldoe's love, but to no purpoſe:
But for your bond-woman.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Let her pine ●●d dye;
She remov'd; which like a brighter ſun,
Obſcures my beames, I may ſhine out againe,
And as I have been, be admir'd and ſought to:
How long has ſhe to live?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Lady, before
The Sun twice riſe and ſet, be confident,
She is but dead; I know my Charme hath found her
Nor can the Governours guard; her lovers teares;
Her Fathers ſorrow, or his power that freed her,
Defend her from it.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: All things have ſucceeded,
As you could wiſh; I ſaw her brought ſick home;
The image of pale death, ſtampt on her fore-head.
Let me adore this ſecond Hecate,
This great Commandreſſe, of the fatall ſiſters,
That as ſhe pleaſes, can cut ſhort, or lengthen
The threed of life.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Where was ſhe, when the inchantment
Firſt ceas'd upon her.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Taking the freſh aire,
In the company of the Governour, and Count Clodio
Arnoldo too, was preſent with her Father,
When, in a moment (ſo the ſervants told me)
As ſhe was giving thanks to the Governour,
And Clodio, for her unexpected freedome,
As if ſhe had been blaſted, ſhe ſunk down,
To their amazement.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: 'Tis thy maſter-piece
Which I will ſo reward, that thou ſhalt fixe here,
And with the hazard of thy life, no more
Make tryall of thy powerfull Art; which known
Our Lawes call death: off with this Magicall robe,
And be thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Stand cloſe, you ſhall heare more.

sp.speaker: Go: Man.
sp.l: You muſt have patience; all rage is vain now,
And piety forbids, that we ſhould queſtion
What is decreed above, or aske a reaſon
Why heaven determines this or that way of us.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Heaven has no hand in't; 'tis a work of hell.
Her life hath been ſo innocent, all her actions
So free from the ſuſpition of crime,
As rather ſhe deſerves a Saints place here,
Then to endure, what now her ſweeteneſſe ſuffers.

sp.speaker: Charin.
sp.l: Not for her fault, but mine Sir; Zenocia ſuffers,
The ſin I made, when I ſought to raſe downe
Arnoldos love, built, on a Rock of truth,
Now to the height is puniſh'd. I profeſſe,
Had he no birth, nor parts, the preſent ſorrowes
He now expreſſes for her, does deſerve her
Above all Kings, though ſuch had been his riuals.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: All Ancient ſtories, of the love of husbands
To vertuous wives, be now no more remembred.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: The tales of Turtles, ever be forgotten,
Or, for his ſake beleev'd.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I have heard, there has been
Betweene ſome married paires, ſuch ſympathy,
That th' husband, has felt really, the throwes
His wife then teeming ſuffers, this true griefe,
Confirms, 'tis not impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Wee ſhall finde
Fit time for this hereafter; lets' uſe now
All poſſible meanes to help her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Care, nor coſt,
Nor what Phyſitians can do, ſhall be wanting;
Make uſe of any meanes, or men.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You are noble. Exeunt. Man. Clod. Charino.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Ten Colledges of Doctors ſhall not ſave her.
Her fate is in your hand.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Can I reſtore her?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: If you command my Art.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I'le dye my ſelfe firſt.
And yet I'le goe viſit her, and ſee
This miracle of ſorrow in Arnoldo:
And 'twere for me, I ſhould change places with her,
And dye moſt happy, ſuch a lovers teares,
Were a rich monument, but too good for her;
Whoſe miſery I glory in: come Sulpitia,
You ſhall a long with me, good Zabulon
Be not farr off.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: I will attend you Madam. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I have ſerv'd you, from my youth, and ever
You have found me faithfull: that you lives a treaſure
I'le locke up here; nor ſhall it be let forth,
But when you give me warrant.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I rely,
Vpon thy faith; nay, no more proteſtations,
Too many of them, will call that in queſtion,
Which now I doubt not, ſhe is there.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Alone too
But take it on my life your entertainment,
Appearing as you are, will bee but courſe
For the diſpleaſure, I ſhall undergoe;
I am prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Leave me, I'le ſtand the hazard. Exit Servant.
The ſilence that's obſerv'd, her cloſe retirements
No viſitance admitted, not the day;
Theſe ſable colours, all ſignes of true ſorrow,
Or hers is deeply counterfeit. I'le looke neerer,
Manners give leave—ſhe fits upon the ground;
By heaven ſhe weepes; my picture in her hand too;
She kiſſes it and weepes againe.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Whoſe there?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: There is no ſtarting back now Madam.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Ha, another murderer, I'le not protect thee,
Though I have no more Sonnes.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Your pardon Lady,
Ther's no ſuch foule fact taints me

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: What makes thou here then?
Where are my Servants, do none but my ſorrowes
Attend upon me? ſpeake, what brought thee hither?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: A will, to give you comfort.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Thou art but a man.
And 'tis beyond a humane reach to do it
If thou could raiſe the dead out of their graues.
Bid time run back, make me now what I was,
A happy Mother: gladly I would heare thee,
But that's impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Pleaſe you but to read this;
You ſhall know better there, why I am ſent
Then if I ſhould deliver it

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: From whom comes it?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: That will inſtruct you; I ſuſpect this ſtranger,
Yet ſhe ſpake ſomething, that holds ſuch alliance,
With his reports I know not what to thinke on't;
What a frown was ther? ſhe looks me through, & through,
Now reades againe, now pauſes, and now ſmiles;
And yet there's more of anger in't then mirth,
Theſe are ſtrange changes; oh I underſtand it
She's full of ſerious thoughts.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: You are juſt you Heavens,
And never do forget to heare their prayers,
That truly pay their vowes, the defer'd vengeance,
For you, and my words ſake ſo long defer'd,
Under which as a mountaine, my heart groanes yet
When 'twas diſpair'd of, now is offerd to me;
And if I looſe it, I am both wayes guilty,
The womans maske, diſſimulation help me;
Come hither freind, I am ſure you know the Gentleman,
That ſent theſe charms.

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: Charms Lady?

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Theſe charms.
I well may call them ſo, th'ave won upon me,
More then ere letter did; thou art his freind,
(The confidence he has in thee, confirmes it)
And therefore I'le be open breaſted to thee,
To heare of him, though yet, I never ſaw him,
Was moſt deſir'd of all men; let me bluſh,
And then I'le ſay I love him.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: All men ſee,
In this a womans vertue.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I expected
For the courteſie I did, long ſince to have ſeene him,
And though I then forbad it, you men know,
Betweene our harts and tongues, there's a large diſtance;
But I'le excuſe him, may be hitherto,
He has forborne it, in reſpect my Sonne
Fell by his hand.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: And reaſon Lady.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: No, he did me a pleaſure in't, a riotous fellow,
And with that inſolent, not worth the owning▪
I have indeed kept a long ſolemne ſorrow,
For my freinds ſake partly; but eſpecially
For his long abſence.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: O the Devill!

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Therefore,
Bid him bee ſpeedy; a Preiſt ſhall be ready
To tye the holy knot; this kiſſe I ſend him,
Deliver that and bring him.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I am dumbe:
A good cauſe I have now, and a good ſword,
And ſomething I ſhall do, I wait upon you. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mannuel. Charino. Arnoldo. Zenocia, borne in a chaire. 2. Doctors. Clodio.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Give her more ayre ſhee dyes elſe.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: O thou dread power,
That mad'ſt this all, and of thy workemanſhip,
This virgin wife, the Maſter peice, looke downe on her;
Let her minds virtues, cloth'd in this faire garment,
That worthily deſerves, a better name
Then fleſh and bloud, now ſue, and prevaile for her.
Or if thoſe are denyed, let innocence,
To which, all paſſages in heaven ſtand open,
Appeare in her white robe, before thy throne;
And mediate for her: or if this age of ſinne,
Be worthy of a miracle, the Sun
In his diurnall progreſſe never ſaw,
So ſweete a ſubject to imploy it on.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Wonders are ceaſ'd Sir, we muſt worke by meanes,

sp.speaker: Arno.
sp.l: 'Tis true and ſuch reverend Phyſitians are;
To you—thus low I fall then; ſo may you ever
Be ſtil'd the hands of heaven, natures reſtorers;
Get wealth and honours; and by your ſucceſſe,
In all your undertakings, propagate
Your great opinion in the world, as now
You uſe your ſaving Art; for know good Gentlemen.
Beſides the fame, and all that I poſſeſs,
For a reward, poſterity ſhall ſtand
Indebted to you, for (as heaven forbid it)
Should my Zen●cia dye, robbing this age,
Of all that's good or gracefull, times ſucceeding,
The ſtory of her pure life not yet perfect,
Will ſuffer in the want of her example.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Were all the world to periſh with her, wee
Can do no more; then what art and experience
Gives us aſſurance of, we have uſ'd all meanes
To finde the cauſe of her diſeaſe, yet cannot;
How ſhould we then, promiſe the cure?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Away,
I did bely you, when I charg'd you with
The power of doing; yee are meere names only,
And even your beſt perfection, accidentall;
What ever malady thou art, or ſpirit,
As ſome hold, all diſeaſes that afflict us,
As love, already makes me ſenſible
Of halfe her ſufferings, eaſe her of her part,
And let me ſtand the butt, of thy fell malice,
And I will ſweare th'art mercifull.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Your hand Lady;
What a ſtrange heat is heare? bring ſome warme water.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: She ſhall uſe nothing that is yours; my ſorrow,
Provides her of a better bath, my teares,
Shall do that office.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: O my beſt Arnoldo!
The trueſt of all lovers! I would live
Were heaven ſo pleaſ'd, but to reward your ſorrow,
With my true ſervice; but ſince that's denied me,
May you live long and happy: do not ſuffer,
(By your affection to me I conjure you)
My ſickneſſe to infect you; though much love
Makes you too ſubject to it.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: In this onely
Zenocia Wrongs her ſervant; can the body
Subſiſt, the ſoule departed? 'tis as eaſy
As I to live without you; I am your husband,
And long have been ſo, though our adverſe fortune,
Banding us, from one hazard to another,
Would never grant me ſo much happineſſe,
As to pay a husbands debt; deſpite of fortune,
In death I'le follow you, and guarde mine owne;
And there enjoy what heere my fate forbids me.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: So true a ſorrow, and ſo feelingly
Expreſt, I never read of.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I am ſtrooke
With wonder to behold it, as with pitty

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: If you that are a ſtranger, ſuffer for them,
Being tied no further then humanity
Leades you to ſoft compaſſion; thinke great Sir,
What of neceſſity I muſt endure,
That am a Father?

div.stage: Hypolita. Zabulon and Sulpitia at the dore.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Waite me there, I hold it
Unfit to have you ſeene; as I finde cauſe,
You ſhall proceed,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You are welcome Lady.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: Sir, I come to do a charitable office,
How does the patient?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: You may enquire
Of more then one; for two are ſick, and deadly,
He languiſhes in her, her healths, deſpaird of,
And in hers, his.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: 'Tis a ſtrange ſpectacle,
With what a patience, they ſit unmov'd?
Are they not dead already?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: By her pulſe,
She cannot laſt a day.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Oh by that ſummons,
I know my time too!

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: Looke to the man.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Apply
Your Art, to ſave the Lady, preſerve her,
A towne is your reward.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: I'le treble it,
In ready gold, if you reſtore Arnoldo;
For in his death I dye too.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: without her,
I am no more.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Are you there Madam? now
You may feaſt on my miſeries; my coldneſſe
In anſwering your affections; or hardneſſe,
Give it what name you pleaſe, you are reveng'd of;
For now you may perceive, our thred of life
Was ſpun together, and the poore Arnoldo,
Made only to enjoy the beſt Zenocia,
And not to ſerve the uſe of any other;
And in that ſhe may equall, my Lord Clodio,
Had long ſince elſe enjoyed her, nor could I
Have been ſo blinde, as not to ſee your great
And many excellencies farr, farr beyond
Or my deſervings, or my hopes; we are now
Going our lateſt journey, and together,
Our onely comfort we deſire, pray give it
Your charitie to our aſhes, ſuch wee muſt be,
And not to curſe our memoryes.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: I am much mov'd.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I am wholly overcome, all love to women,
Farewell for ever, ere you dye, your pardon;
And yours Sir; had ſhe many yeares to live,
Perhaps I might looke on her, as a Brother,
But as a lover never; and ſince all
Your ſad misfortunes, had originall
From the barbarous cuſtome practiz'd in my Countrey,
Heaven witneſſe, for your ſake I here releaſe it;
So to your memory, chaſt Wives and Virgins
Shall ever pay their vowes. I give her to you;
And wiſh, ſhe were ſo now, as when my luſt
Forc'd you; to quite the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: It is in vaine,
To ſtrive with deſtiny, here my dotage ends,
Looke up Zenocin, health in me ſpeakes to you;
She giues him to you, that by divers wayes,
So long has kept him from you: and repent not,
That you were once my ſervanr, for which health
In recompence of what I made you ſuffer,
The hundred thouſand Crownes, the Citie owes me,
Shall be your dower.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis a magnificent guift,
Had it beene timely given.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: It is beleeve it; Sulpitia?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Madam

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Quicke, undoe the charme;
Aske not a reaſon why; let it ſuffice,
It is my will.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Which I obey and gladly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Is to be married ſayeſt thou?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: So ſhe ſayes ſir,
And does deſire your preſence. They are borne off in chaires

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And tell her i'le come.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Pray carry them to their reſt; for though already,
They do appeare as dead, let my life pay for't,
If they recover not.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What you have warranted,
Aſſure your ſelfe, will be expected from you;
Looke to them carefully; and till the tryall,

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: Which ſhall not be above foure howers.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Let me
Intreate your companies: there is ſomething
Of waight, invites me hence.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: weell waite upon you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: You underſtand what my directions are,
And what they guide you to; the faithfull promiſe,
You have made me all.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We do and will performe it.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: The Governour will not faile to be here preſently
Retire a while, till you ſhall finde occaſion,
And bring me word, when they arrive.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Wee ſhall Madam.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Onely ſtay you to entertaine;

sp.speaker: 1. Ser
sp.l: I am ready

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I wonder at the bold, and practis'd malice,
Men ever haue a foote, againſt our honours,
That nothing we can do, never ſo verteous,
No ſhape put on ſo pious, no not thinke
What a good is, be that good ne're ſo noble,
Never ſo Laden with admir'd example,
But ſtill we end in luſt; our aimes our actions,
Nay, even our charities, with luſt are branded;
Why ſhould this ſtranger elſe, this wretched ſtranger,
Whoſe life I ſav'd at what deare price, ſtick here yet?
Why ſhould he hope, he was not here an hower,
And certainly in that time, I may ſweare it
I gave him no looſe looke, I had no reaſon;
Unleſſe my teares were flames, my curſes courtſhips;
The killing of my Sonne, a kindneſſe to me,
Why ſhould he ſend to me, or with what ſafety
(Examining the ruine he had wrought me)
Though at that time, my pious pitty found him,
And my word fixt; I am troubled, ſtrongly troubled.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Gentlemen are come,

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Then bid 'em welcome—I muſt retire. Exit.
You are welcome home Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I thank you freind, I would ſpeak with your Lady.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I'le let her underſtand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: It ſhall befit you,
How do I looke Sir, in this handſome trim? Exit. Servant.
Me thinks I am woundrous brave.

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: You are very decent.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Theſe by themſelves, without more helps of nature,
Would ſet a woman hard; I know 'em all,
And where their firſt aimes light; I'le lay my head on't,
I'le take her eye, as ſoone as ſhe lookes on me,
And if I come to ſpeake once, woe be to her,
I have her in a nooze, ſhe cannot ſcape me;
I have their ſeverall laſts.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: You are throughly ſtudied,
But tel me Sir, being unacquainted with her,
As you confeſſe you are—

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: That's not an howers worke,
I'le make a nun forget her beades in two houres.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: She being ſet in yeares next, none of thoſe luſters
Appearing in her eye,, that warme the fancy;
Nor nothing in her face, but handſome ruines.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I love old ſtoryes; thoſe live beleev'd, Authentique,
When 20. of your moderne faces, are cald in,
For new opinion paintings, and corruptions,
Give me an old confirm'd face; beſides ſhe ſav'd me,
She ſav'd my life, have I not cauſe to love her?
Shee's rich and of a conſtant ſtate, a faire one
Have I not cauſe to wooe her? I have tryed ſufficient,
All your young Phillies, I thinke this back has tryed 'em,
And ſmarted for it too: they run away with me,
Take bitt betweene the teeth, and play the Divels;
A ſtaied pace now becomes my yeares; a ſure one,
Where I may ſit and cracke no girthes.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: How miſerable,
If my Mother ſhould confirme, what I ſuſpect now,
Beyond all humane cure were my condition?
Then I ſhall wiſh, this body had been ſo too,
Here comes the Lady Sir.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Excellent Lady,
To ſhew I am a creature, bound to your ſervice,
And onely yours—

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Keepe at that diſtance Sir;
For if you ſtirr—

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I am obedient,
She has found already, I am for her turne;
With what a greedy hawkes eye ſhe beholds me?
Marke how ſhe muſters all my parts.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: A goodly Gentleman,
Of a more manly ſet, I never look'd on.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Marke, marke her eye ſtill; marke but the carriage of 'em

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: How happy am I now; ſince my Sonne fell,
He fell not, by a baſe unnoble hand?
As that ſtill troubled me; how farr more happy
Shall my revenge be, ſince the ſacrifice,
I offer to his grave, ſhall be both worthy,
A Sonnes untimely loſſe, and a Mothers ſorrow?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Sir, I am made beleeve it; ſhe is mine owne,
I told you what a ſpell I carried with me,
All this time does ſhe ſpend, in contemplation,
Of that unmatch'd delight: I ſhall be thankfull to yee;
And if you pleaſe to know my houſe, to uſe it;
To take it for your owne.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Who waites without there?

div.stage: Enter. Guard. and Servants. they ſeize upon Rut. & bind him.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: How now? what meanes this, Lady?

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Binde him faſt.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Are theſe the bride-laſes you prepare for me?
The colours that you give?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Fy gentle Lady,
This is not noble dealing.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Be you ſatiffied,
It ſeemes you are a ſtranger to this meaning,
You ſhall not be ſo long

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Do you call this wooing—Is there no end of womens perſecutions?
Muſt I needs foole into mine owne deſtruction?
Have I not had faire warnings, and enough too?
Still pick the Divells teeth? you are not mad Lady;
Do I come fairely, and like a Gentleman,
To offer you that honour?

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd Sir
You come beſotted, to your owne deſtruction:
I ſent not for you; what honour can ye add to me,
That brake that ſtaffe of honour, my age lean'd on?
That robd me of that right, made me a Mother?
Heare me thou wretched man, heare me with terrour,
And let thine owne bold folly ſhake thy ſoule,
Heare me pronounce thy death, that now hangs o're thee,
Thou deſperate foole; who bad thee ſeeke this ruine?
What mad unmanly fate, made thee diſcover
Thy curſed face to me againe? waſt not enough
To have the faire protection of my houſe,
When miſery and juſtice, clooſe perſued thee?
When thine owne bloudy ſword, cryed out againſt thee,
Hatcht in the life of him? yet I forgave thee;
My hoſpitable word, even when I ſaw
The goodlieſt branch of all my blood, lopt from me,
Did I not Seale ſtill to thee?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I am gon.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: And when thou went'ſt to Impe thy miſerie,
Did I not give thee meanes? but harke ungratefull,
Was it not thus? to hide thy face and fly me?
To keep thy name for ever from my memory?
Thy curſed blood and kindred; did I not ſweare then
If ever, (in this wretched life thou haſt left me,
Short and unfortunate,) I ſaw thee againe,
Or came but to the knowledge, where thou wanderdſt,
To call my vowe back, and purſue with vengance
With all the miſeryes a Mother ſuffers?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I was borne to be hang'd, there's no auoyding it.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: And dar'ſt thou with this impudence appeare here?
Walke like the winding ſheete my Sonne was put in,
Stand with thoſe wounds?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I am happy now againe;
Happy the hower I fell, to finde a Mother,
So pious good, and excellent in ſorrowes.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Governours come in.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: O let him enter.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I have fool'd my ſelfe a faire thred of all my fortunes,
This ſtrikes me moſt; not that I feare to periſh,
But that this unmanerly boldneſſe, has brought me to it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Are theſe fit preparations for a wedding Lady?
I came prepar'd a gueſt.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: O give me juſtice;
As ever you will leave a vertuous name,
Do juſtice, juſtice, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: You need not aske it,
I am bound to it.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Iuſtice upon this man
That kild my Sonne.

sp.speaker: Gove.
sp.l: Do you confeſſe the act?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: 'Tis the ſame.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: How fell he thus?
Here will be ſorrow for the good Arnoldo.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Take heed Sir what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I have weigh'd it well,
I am the man, nor is it life I ſtart at;
Onely I am unhappy I am poore,
Doore in expence of lives, there I am wretched,
That I have not two lives lent me for his ſacrifice;
One for her Sonne, another for her ſorrowes.
Excellent Lady, now rejoyce againe,
For though I cannot thinke, y'are pleas'd in blood,
Nor with that greedy thirſt purſue your vengeance;
The tenderneſſe, even in thoſe teares denies that;
Yet let the world beleeve, you lov'd Duarte;
The unmatcht courteſies you have done my miſeries,
Without this forfeite to the law, would charge me
To tender you this life, and proud t'would pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Shall I have juſti●e?

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I'le aske it for ye,
I'le follow it my ſelfe, againſt my ſelfe.
Sir, 'Tis moſt ſit I dye; diſpatch it quickly,
The monſtrous burthen of that griefe ſhe labours with
Will kill her elſe, then blood on blood lyes on me;
Had I a thouſand liues, I'd give e'm all,
Before I would draw one teare more from that vertue.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Be not too cruell Sir, and yet his bold ſword—
But his life cannot reſtore that he's a man too—
Of a faire promiſe, but alas my Sonnes dead;
If I have juſtice, muſt it kill him?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: If I have not, it kills me, ſtrong and goodly!
Why ſhould he periſh too?

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: It lies in your power,
You onely may accuſe him, or may quitt him.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Be there no other witneſſes?

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Not any.
And if I ſave him, will not the world proclaime,
I have forgot a Sonne, to ſave a murderer?
And yet he lookes not like one, he lookes manly.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Pitty ſo brave a Gentleman ſhould periſh.
She cannot be ſo hard, ſo cruell harted.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Will you pronounce? yet ſtay a little Sir.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Rid your ſelfe Lady, of this miſery;
And let me go, I do but breed more tempeſts,
With which you are already, to much ſhaken.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: Do now, pronounce; I will not heare.

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: You ſhall not,
Yet turne and ſee good Madam.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Do not wonder.
'Tis he, reſtor'd againe, thanke the good Doctor,
Pray do not ſtand amaz'd, it is Duarte;
Is well, is ſafe againe.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: O my ſweete Sonne.
I will not preſſe my wonder now with queſtions—
Sir, I am ſorry for that cruelty,
I urg'd againſt you.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Madam it was but juſtice.

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: 'Tis true, the Doctor heald this body againe,
But this man heald my ſoule, made my minde perfect,
The good ſharp leſſons his ſword read to me, ſav'd me;
For which, if you lov'd me deare Mother,
Honour and love this man.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: You ſent this letter,

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: My boldneſſe makes me bluſh now.

sp.speaker: Guio.
sp.l: I'le wipe of that,
And with this kiſſe, I take you for my husband,
Your woings done Sir; I beleeve you love me,
And that's the wealth I looke for now.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: You have it.

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: You have ended my deſire to all my wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Now 'tis a wedding againe. And if Hypollita,
Make good, what with the hazard of her life,
She undertooke, the evening will ſett cleare.
sp.stage: Enter. Hypollita. leading Leopold. Arnoldo. Zenocia. in either hand. Zabulon. Sulpitia.
sp.l: After a ſtormy day.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Here comes the Lady.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: With faire Zenocia,
Health with life againe,
Reſtor'd unto her.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: The guift of her goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Let us embrace, I am of your order too,
And though I once deſpair'd of women, now,
I finde they relliſh much of Scorpions,
For both have ſtings, and both can hurt, and cure too;
But what have been your fortunes?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Wee'le defer
Our ſtory, and at time more fit, relate it.
Now all that reverence vertue, and in that
Zenocias conſtancy, and perfect love,
Or for her ſake Arnoldo, joyne with us
In th' honour of this Lady.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: She deſerves it.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: Hypollitas life, ſhall make that good hereafter,
Nor will I alone, better my ſelfe but others:
For theſe whoſe wants perhaps, have made their actions
Not altogether innocent, ſhall from me
Be ſo ſupplied; that need ſhould not compell them,
To any courſe of life, but what the law
Shall give allowance to.

sp.speaker: Zab.
sp.l: Sulp. Your Ladiſhipps creatures.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Be ſo and no more, you man-huckſter.

sp.speaker: Hypo.
sp.l: And worthy Leopold, you that with ſuch fervour,
So long have ſought me, and in that deſerv'd me,
Shall now finde full reward, for all your travelles,
Which you have made more deare, by patient ſufferance.
And though my violent dotage did tranſport me,
Beyond thoſe bounds, my modeſty ſhould have kept in,
Though my deſires were looſe, from unchaſt art,
Heaven knows I am f●ee.

sp.speaker: Leop.
sp.l: The thought of that's dead to me;
I gladly take your offer.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Do ſo Sir,
A peice of crackt gold, ever will weigh downe
Siluer that's whole.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You ſhall be all my gueſts,
I muſt not be denyed.

sp.speaker: Arno.
sp.l: Come my Zenocia.
Our barke at length has found a quiet harbour;
And the unſpotted progreſſe of our loves
Ends not alone in ſafety but reward,
To inſtruct others, by our faire example;
That though good purpoſes, are long withſtood,
The hand of Heaven ſtill guides ſuch as are good.

div.head: The Prologue.
div.l: SO free this worke is, Gentlemen, from offence,
That we are confident, it needes no defence
From us, or from the Poets—wee dare looke.
On any man, that brings his Table-booke
To write downe, what againe he may repeate
At ſome greate Table, to deſerve his meate.
Let ſuch come ſweld with malice, to apply
What it mirth here, there for an injurie.
Nor Lord, nor Lady we have tax'd; nor State,
Nor any private perſon, their poore hate
Will be ſtarv'd heere, for envy ſhall not finde,
One touch that may be wreſted to her minde.
And yet deſpaire not Gentlemen, The play
Is quicke and witty; ſo the Poets ſay,
And we believe them; the plott neate, and new,
Faſhiond like thoſe, that are approv'd by you.
Onely 'twill crave attention, in the moſt;
Becauſe one point unmark'd, the whole is loſt
Heare firſt then, and judge after, and be free,
And as our cauſe is, let our cenſure be.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: WHy there ſhould be an Epilogue to a Play.
I know no cauſe, the old and uſuall way,
For which they were made, was to entreat the grace
Of ſuch as were ſpectators in this place,
And time, 'tis to no purpoſe; for I know
What you reſolve already to beſtow,
Will not be alterd, what ſo ere I ſay,
In the behalfe of us, and of the Play:
Onely to quitt our doubts, if you thinke fit,
You may, or cry it up; or ſilence it.

div.head: Another Prologue for the Cuſtome of the Countrey. For my Sonne Clarke.
div.l: WEe wiſh, if it were poſſible, you knew
What we would give for this nights looke, if new?
It being our ambition to delight
Our kinde ſpectators with what's good, and right.
Yet ſo farre know, and credite me, 'twas made
By ſuch, as were held work-men in their Trade,
At a time too, when they as I divine,
Were truly merrie, and dranke luſty wine.
The nectar of the Muſes; Some are here
I dare preſume, to whom it did appeare.
A well-drawne piece, which gave a lawfull birth
To paſſionate Scoenes mixt with no vulgar mirth.
But unto ſuch to whom 'tis knowne by fame
From others, perhaps only by the name.
I am a ſuitor, that they would prepare
Sound palats, and then judge their bill of fare.
It were injuſtice to decry this now
For being like'd before, you may allow
(Your candor ſafe) what's taught in the olde ſchooles,
All ſuch as liv'd before you, were not fooles.

div.head: The Epilogue.
div.l: I Spake much in the Prologue for the Play,
To its deſert I hope, yet you might ſay
Should I change now from that, which then was meant,
Or in a ſyllable grow leſſe confident.
I were weake-hearted. I am ſtill the ſame
In my opinion, and forbeare to frame
Qualification, or excuſe: If you
Concur with me, and hold my judgement true.
Shew it with any ſigne, and from this place,
Or ſend me off exploded, or with grace.
